sp.p: Satni was one of yours , and you defend him .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: We must not make martyrs — if we can avoid it . In killing Satni you would have killed only a man . If what I dream succeed , I shall kill his work . That is a better thing .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: What will you make of him ?

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: A priest .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: A priest ?

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: He was initiated before he went away . He was then a young man , pious and wise . On his travels he lost some piety , and gained some wisdom .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: Have I not always said : “ it is not good to travel . ”

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: I think like you . Travellers learn too much . Yet am I hopeful . I shall bring him back to our gods .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: You will fail .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: He who for long has breathed the air of temples can never wholly clear his breast of it . If he give way , he shall never leave the house of the Gods again , if he be still rebellious , he shall leave to go to his death .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: I order you to give Satni up to me .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: I would I might bow to your will . But he is a priest : his life is sacred . And I may not transgress the orders given me by the Gods .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: Prate not of these follies to me — do you take me for one of your priests ? Obey ! I command you !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Do you take me for one of your soldiers ?

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: I command it .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: The gods forbid .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: I laugh at your gods .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Beware lest your people hear .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: I would be master , in truth . And more , I refuse to submit to the humiliation that again you put on me a while ago .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: How should that humiliate you ? Before you , the highest bow down .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: Yes . And straightway , then , I must bow me down before you .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: You salute , not me , but the god whom I represent .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: I pay homage to the god , it is the priest who receives it . HIGH PRIESTfaintly smilingRest assured ! I pass it on to him .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: And you mock me , besides ! Oh ! if I but dared to kill you , hypocrite !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Vain man !

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: You tremble at sight of a sword , coward !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Being a butcher , you know only how to kill .

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: Liar !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Who made you Pharaoh ?

sp.speaker: THE PHARAOH
sp.p: Beware lest one day I have you thrown to my lions !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Beware lest one day I strike the crown of the two Egypts from your head , telling the people the god has set his face against you !A pauseCome , we must work together . We complete each other . To govern men , we have both the reality of the evils you inflict on them , and the hope of the good I promise them . Believe me , we must work together . The day that one of us disappears , the fate of the other will be in jeopardy — I perceive they make sign to me . They think our prayers are long and fervent . The hour is come for you to receive the acclamation of your people , and follow them to the shrine of Isis — when Satni will not prevent the miracle , I pledge my word to that . The cortége comes on and goes out with Pharaoh . Satni is led before the High Priest .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: You know me again ! SATNItroubledYes , you are the High Priest . HIGH PRIESTwith sweet gentlenessI , too , I know you again . Your father is a potter . You were brought up and taught by us . In the crowd of neophytes I singled you out by your gentleness , your great intelligence ; and I saw you destined for the highest dignities . I esteemed you , I was fond of you . We took you from wretchedness . What you know , for the most part , you owe to us . This thing that you have done should anger me — I am only sad , my son .A pauseYou are troubled .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Yes , I looked for threats , for torture . The kindness of your voice unmans me .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Be not distressed . Forget who I am . None hear us . Let us talk together as father and son . Or better , since your learning makes you worthy , as two men . You have proclaimed broadcast that the miracle will not come to pass .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: The goddess is stone . Stone does not move itself . The image will not bow its head unless man intervene .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: That is evident .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: You admit it ?

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: To you , yes . We give to each one the faith he deserves . Had you remained with us , at each step in the priesthood you would have beheld the gods rise with you , become more immaterial , more noble , as you became more learned . We give to the people the gods they can understand . Our god is different . He is the one who exists in essence . The one who lives in substance , the sole procreator who was not engendered , the father of the fathers , the mother of mothers . The one and only . And we crave his pardon for belittling him by miracles . But they are part of that faith which alone contents the simple-minded . You are above them — I admit freely that the miracle could be prevented . You declared it would not take place — you have found the means to make it impossible ? SATNIsuspecting the trapI said that , left to herself , the goddess would not move .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: To say only that , would not have served you . You intended to prevent the miracle . Come , admit it — it is so .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Perhaps .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: By seizing you , I prevent your committing the sacrilege . Your purpose will not be realized . In an hour the festival of the Prodigy will take place , and you are my prisoner . It follows then , the miracle will be performed — you believe that , do you not ? SATNIafter a pauseYes , I believe it .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: And so your cause is lost .A pauseListen to me ; the priests who have taken their final vows are as wise and as little credulous as you . I offer you a place among them . Return to us . A little wisdom banishes the gods — great wisdom brings them back .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: I refuse .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: My son , my son , you will not cause me this sorrow . Think what you will drive me to , if you refuse — Satni , do not force me to send you before the tribunal , whose sentence must be death . Death , for you , so young , whose future is so bright !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: I do not fear death .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Besides — I mind me — you were betrothed to that little Yaouma whom the god has chosen as victim . You know she may be saved from the sacrifice , if she become the wife of a priest . They guarded her but ill at Rheou 's house , she is here . I have seen her ; she is kind and gentle , and you would lead a happy life with her .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Yaouma ! Yaouma !He hides his faceHIGH PRIESTlaying a hand on his shoulderSo that on one side is Yaouma 's death and yours ; on the other , happiness with her — and power . Say nothing . I speak as a father might , you can see . I say besides , that you will better serve the crowd in leaving them their gods . I wish to convince you of it , and you will stay with us — weep no more . You will stay , will you not ? Wait ! Hear me , before you answer . You seek happiness for the lower orders ? There is no happiness for them without religion . Already you have seen what they become , when it is taken from them . The riots of yesterday cost your father his life . He suffered much , they tell me . Is it true ? I do not know the details . You saw him die , did you not ? Tell me how it happened .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Ah ! I was right . It was in truth torture that awaited me here . You have guessed you would gain nothing racking my body — you keep your torments for my heart .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Have I said other than what is true ? The conversions that your preaching made were followed by disorders — was it not then that your father was wounded ? I knew him . He was a man , simple and good . You are the cause of his death , as you will be the cause of Yaouma 's .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Peace ! You would have my sorrows crush my will !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: I shall speak of them no more . But think of the people of Egypt , what evils you would bring on them ! If you take away their religion , what will keep them virtuous ?

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: What you call their virtue , is only their submission .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: You let loose their vilest instincts , if you remove the fear of the gods .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: The fear of the gods has prevented fewer crimes than were needed to create it .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Be it so . But it exists .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: It is your interest to spread the belief , that the fear of the gods is a restraint . And you know that it is not . You do not leave the punishment of crime to the gods . You have the lash , hard labor in the mines ; you have scaffolds , you have executioners . No one believes sincerely in the happy life beyond the grave . If we believed , we should kill ourselves , the sooner to reach the Island of the Souls , the fields of Yalou .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: By what then are the appetites restrained ?

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: By the laws , by the need of the esteem of others —

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: We have just seen that , in sooth . So then it was virtue that the people showed yesterday , after you made them break their gods ? They seemed to care little for the esteem of others , for they stole , they pillaged , they killed . Do you approve of that ? Have they gained your esteem , those who have done what they have done ?

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Oh , I know ! I know ! That is your strongest argument . Creatures degraded by centuries of slavery , drunk with the first hours of freedom , commit crimes . You argue from this , that they were meant for slaves . Yes , it is true that if you take a child from the leading strings that upheld it , the child falls down . But you who watch over it , you rejoice at the fall , for then you can assert that the child must go back to its leading strings — and be kept in them till death .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Then you declare that all supports must be suppressed ?A pauseReligion is a prop . It soothes — consoles . He does evil who disturbs it .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Many religions died before ours . The passing of each caused the sorrows you foresee . Should we then have kept the first , to prevent some suffering ?

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Ours is yet young , though so old ; look in the halls of our temples , behold the countless thank-offerings brought there for prayers that were granted .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Your temples could not hold the offerings , unthinkable in number , that those whose prayers were not granted might have made , and who none the less prayed as well as the others .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Even unanswered their prayers were recompensed . They had hope , and it is likewise a boon to the poor to promise them welfare in the world to come .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: You promise them welfare in the world to come , to make them forget that all the welfare in this world is yours .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Can you give happiness to all who are on earth ? We are more generous than you ; at least we give them consolation .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: You make them pay dear for it .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: In truth the granaries of our temples are full to overflowing . Left to themselves , the people would not think of the lean years , in the years of abundance . We think for them , and they bring us , gladly , what they would refuse did they not believe they gave to the gods . We proclaim the Nile sacred ; it is forbidden to sully its waters . Is that to honor it as a god ? Not so , it is to avoid the plague . And all the animals we deified are those man has need of . You did not learn all things on your travels —

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: You would have the peasant remain a child , because you fear the reckoning he would demand of you , if you let him grow up . You know you could not stay him then by showing him the god-jackal , the god-ram , the god-bull , and the rest that do not exist .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Are you certain they do not exist ?

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Know you where you are ?

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: In the temple .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: In the temple ; where you were brought up . There was a time when you dared not have crossed the first sacred enclosure . You are in the third . Look round ! There is the holy of holies . At my will the stones that mask the entrance will roll back , and the goddess will be unveiled . Except the High Priest and the Pharaoh , no mortal , if he be not priest himself , may look on her and live — save at the hour of the annual Festival of Prodigies , which is upon us now . Do you believe that you can endure to be alone in her presence ?

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: I do believe it .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: We shall see . If you be afraid , call and prostrate yourself . Afterwards you shall go and tell what you have seen , to those whom you deceived . The High Priest makes a sign . Total darkness . A peal of thunder .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Ah !Terrified , he leaps forward . A faint light returns slowly , the temple is emptyI am alone !He is terrified , standing erect against a pillar facing the audienceAlone in the temple , within sight of the goddess almost . I know ‘ tis but an image — yet am I steeped in terror , even to the marrow of my bones .He utters an agonized cryAh !— I thought I beheld in the darkness — No — I know that there is nothing — Oh ! coward nature ! Because I was cradled amid tales of religion , because I grew up in the fear of the gods , because my father and my father 's father , and all those from whom I come , were crushed by this terror even from the blackest night of time , I tremble , and my reason totters . All this is false , I know — the god obeys the priest . Yet , from these towering columns , horror and mystery descend upon me —A thunder clap brings him to his knees . The stones that mask the entrance to the sanctuary roll slowly back . He tries to lookThe holy of holies opens — I am afraid — I am afraid —He mutters words , wipes the sweat from his brow with his hand . He trembles and falls sobbing to the ground . A long pause‘ Tis the beast in me that is afraid — Ah ! coward flesh !Biting his handsI shall conquer thee — I would chastise my weakness . I am shamed — I am shamed — In spite of all I will look her in the face . I have the will ! but I must fight against so many memories , against all the dead whose spirits stir in mine . I shall conquer the dead . My life , and my will — courage ! With great effort and after many struggles he gains the mastery of himself , goes to the shrine and looks upon the goddess . The High Priest reappears touching him on the shoulder .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Terror does not move you . Let us see if you be proof against pity . Come —He leads him to the side of the shrine , presses a spring and a door opens , revealing in the interior of the shrine the machinery of the miracle , a lever and cordageLook ! ‘ Tis by pressing this lever that one of ours , in a little while , will bring about the miracle . I leave you in his place . At my signal the doors of the sacred enclosure will open , and the people draw near the sanctuary . Listen to them . And if you are moved to pity by their prayers , you — you shall give them the consoling lie for which they pray .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: There will be no miracle .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Watch and hear .He leaves Satni , who remains visible to the audience . The stones roll back over the shrine . The High Priest makes a sign , other priests appearAll is ready ?

sp.speaker: A PRIEST
sp.p: All . HIGH PRIESTto anotherListen . He whispers to him . The Priest bows and goes out . While the crowd comes in later , this priest is seen to enter the hiding-place right , where he stands watching Satni , dagger in hand .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Now , let them come in . He makes a gesture and all disappear . A pitiable crowd bursts into the temple , bustling , running , filling all the empty spaces . Four men carry a litter on which is a beautiful young woman clothed in precious stuffs . Mieris , Yaouma , and all the characters of the play come on .

sp.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
sp.p: Nearer , lay me nearer the goddess ! She will drive forth the evil spirit that will not let me move my legs . Cripples , people on crutches , creatures with hands or feet wrapped in bandages crowd past her . A BLIND GIRLto him who leads herWhen the stone rolls back and the goddess appears , watch well her face , to tell me if she will not give me back my sight . A paralytic drags himself in on his hands .

sp.speaker: THE PARALYTIC
sp.p: I would be quite near , quite near ! In a little while I shall walk . Two sons lead in their mother , who is mad , striving to calm her . A mother , with her child in her arms , begs the crowd to let her get near . A man , whose head is bandaged , and whose eyes and mouth are mere holes , hustles his neighbors . Many blind , and people borne on chairs .

sp.speaker: A WOMAN
sp.p: She will speak , she will say “ yes . ” She will reveal herself again as protectress of Egypt .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: They say not . They say that great calamities are in store for us .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: If she answer not ?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: Silence !

div.stage: Music . The Pharaoh 's procession enters . He is conducted down left where he remains invisible to the spectators . The High Priest mounts his throne . The people prostrate themselves .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Ammon is great ! A pause .

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.p: Ammon is great !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: The sanctuary is about to open .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: The stones will roll back ! I am afraid ! The goddess will appear ! We shall behold her ! Hush ! Hush ! The High Priest lifts his hands to heaven . A PRIESTin the recess , to some men ready to work the ropes , in a low voiceNow ! The men pull the ropes , the stones roll back . The crowd bow themselves flat on the ground . Those who cannot , hide their faces on their arms .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Rise ! Behold and pray !A smothered cry of terror rises , women mad with terror are seized with nervous fits . They are carried outO goddess ! Thy people adore thee , and humble themselves before thee !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Isis , we adore thee !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: This year , once more , show to us by that miraculous sign of thy divine head , that still thou art our protectress .The people repeat the incantation in a murmurO goddess , if thou hast pity on those who suffer , thou wilt bend thy head . Pity ! Pity ! we suffer ! The evil spirits torment us .

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.p: We suffer ! Drive forth the evil spirits !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Neith ! Mother of the Universe ! The evil spirits torment us ! Neith ! Virgin genetrix ! Isis , sacred earth of Egypt , bend thy head ! Sati , queen of the heavens ! Bend thy head !

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: The soul of a dead man has entered the body of my child , O Isis ! And he is dying . I hold him towards thee , Isis . Behold how he is fair , behold how he suffers . Look , he is so little . Let me keep him ! Isis ! Isis ! Let me keep him !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Pity ! Pity !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Show us that thou dost consent to hear us ! Isis , bend thy head !

sp.speaker: BLIND GIRL
sp.p: Open my eyes ! Ever since I was born a demon held them closed . Let me see the skies of whose splendor they tell me . I am unhappy , Isis ! He whom I love , he who loves me , I have not looked upon his countenance ! I am unhappy , Isis !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Pity ! Pity !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Anouke ! Soul of the Universe ! Pity ! We are before thee like little children who are lost .

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.p: Yes ! Yes ! like little children who are lost !

sp.speaker: THE SON
sp.p: For my father who is blind , Isis , I implore thee !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Isis ! Father ! Pity !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Thmei , Queen of Justice ! Mirror of truth ! Bend thy head !

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG PARALYTIC
sp.p: I have offered up ten lambs to thee . Let me get up and walk ! THE MANwith the bandaged headAn unseen monster devours my face making me howl with pain .

sp.speaker: PARALYZED MAN
sp.p: I drag through the mire , like a beast unclean . Let me walk upright like a god . THE TWO SONSof the mad womanBehold our mother , Isis , behold our mother , who knows us no more , who knows not herself even , and who laughs !—

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: Isis ! Thou art a mother . Isis , in the name of thine own child , save mine . Let me not go with empty arms , bereft of my tender burden . Thou art a mother , Isis !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: All ! All ! Pray ! Supplicate ! Fling you with your faces to the ground — yes ! yes ! again ! Silence ! She is about to answer .A long pauseYour prayers are lukewarm . Your supplications need fervor ! Pray ! Weep ! Cry out ! Cry out !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Isis ! Drive out the evil spirits ! Answer us ! Answer us !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Louder ! Louder !

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.p: Sorrows ! Tears ! Sobs ! Cries ! Have pity !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Once more , though you die !

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.p: Thou dost abandon Egypt ! What ills will overwhelm us ! Help ! Help us ! Have pity !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Have pity ! Have pity !bursting into sobsOh ! unhappy people , Isis , if thou dost abandon them . VOICESamid the sobs of the othersShe hears us not ! She answers not . Evil is upon us ! Evil overwhelms us !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Desperate ! We are desperate !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: We are desperate !

sp.speaker: A CRY
sp.p: Her head is bending ! No ! Yes !

div.stage: Silence . Then a great cry of distress and disappointment .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: O mother ! O goddess !

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: O Isis ! mother of Horus ! the child god ! Wilt thou let die my child ? Behold him ! Behold him !

sp.speaker: YOUNG PARALYTIC
sp.p: Thy heart is hard , O goddess !

sp.speaker: PARALYZED MAN
sp.p: Thou hast but to will it , Isis , and I walk ! THE MANwith the bandaged headHeal my sores ! I sow horror around me ! Heal my sores !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Answer us ! Bend thy head !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Pity ! The crowd , delirious , cries and sobs in a paroxysm of despair .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Oh ! the poor wretched souls ! He presses the lever . As the head of the statue bows , the people respond with one wild roar of acclamation .

div.stage: CURTAIN

div.head: ACT V

stage.stage: SCENE :— Same as Acts I and II .

The statues of the gods are set up again , in their places , facing them a throne has been erected on which the High Priest is seated . Rheou , Satni , Mieris , Yaouma , Sokiti , Nourm , Bitiou , the Steward and all the women and servants of the household , and the laborers . When the curtain rises all are prostrate with their faces to the ground .

HIGH PRIEST [ after a pause ] Rise ! [ All rise to their knees . A pause ] The divine images are again in their places . You have shown that you repent . You have begged for pardon . You have testified your horror of the terrible crime you were driven to commit . You await your chastisement . The gods now permit that we proceed to the sacrifice , that will bring about the overflowing of the Nile , and give for yet another year , life to the land of Egypt . She who has chosen , the elect , the savior , is she here ?
YAOUMA [ rising to her feet , radiant ] I am here !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Let her go to clothe her in the sacred robe . Form the procession to bear her to the threshold of the abode of the glorious and the immortal .

sp.speaker: YAOUMA
sp.p: Come ! A number of the women rise and go out right with Yaouma .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: To-day , at the hour when Ammon-Ra came forth from the underworld , I entered the sanctuary . Face to face with the god , I heard his words , which now you shall hear from me . These are the commands of the God . Rheou !Rheou stands upYou have been to make submission to the Pharaoh — Light of Ra — you have implored his mercy . You have sworn on the body of your father , to serve him faithfully , and you have given that body to him in pledge of your obedience . You have denounced to his anger and justice those who conceived the impious plot to dethrone the Lord of Egypt . You have declared that if you did permit the images of the gods to be thrown down before you , it was because the spells of Satni had clouded your reason . Ammon has proclaimed to me that you are sincere ! You are pardoned , on conditions which I shall presently impart .Rheou bows and kneels downSatni !Satni stands up . He casts down his eyes , he is steeped in sorrow and shameSatni , you have admitted and proclaimed the power of the gods , whom you dared to deny . You have bowed you down before them . Once , in the temple , you took the first priestly vows ; your life is therefore sacred . But you stand now reproved . This very day you will quit Egypt . Withdraw from the Gods !Satni , with eyes on the ground , withdraws , the people shrink aside to let him pass , abusing him in whispers , shaking their fists , and some even striking him . He goes to the terrace down left where he stands , hiding his face on his armAmmon has spoken other words .The people turn from SatniAll you who are here , you are guilty of the most odious , the most monstrous of crimes . You are all deserving of death . Such is the decree of the God .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: O Ammon ! Pity ! Pity ! Ammon !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Cease your sobs ! Cease your cries ! Cease your useless prayers ! Hear the God who speaks through my mouth .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Be kind ! Thou ! Thou ! Have pity ! Beseech the God for us , we implore thee ! We would not die . Not death ! not death ! not death !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Yes — I — I have pity on you . But your crime is so great ! Have you considered well the enormity of your sin ? None can remember to have seen the like . The Gods ! To overthrow the Gods ! And such Gods ! Ammon and Thoueris ! I would I might disarm their wrath . But what shall I offer them in your name that may equal your offence ?

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: All ! Take all we possess , but spare our lives .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: All you possess ! ‘ Tis little enough .

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: Take our crops .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: And who then will feed you ? Already you pay tithes . I will offer a fourth of your harvests for ten years . But ‘ tis little . Even did I say you would give half of all that is in your homes , should I succeed ? And would you give it me ?

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: Yes ! Yes !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Still it will not be enough . Hear what the God hath breathed to me . There must be prayers , ceaseless prayers in the temple . Every year ten of your daughters must enter the house of the God to be consecrated .

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: Our daughters ! Ammon ! Our daughters !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: The God is good ! The God is good ! Lo ! I hear him pronounce the words of pardon . But further , you must needs assist the Pharaoh to carry out the divine commands . Ammon wills that the Ethiopian infidels be chastised . All who are of an age to fight will join the army , that is on the eve of departure . PEOPLEin consternationOh ! the war ! the war !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: Proud Ethiopia threatens invasion to Egypt . You must defend your tombs , your homes , and your women . Would you become slaves of the blacks ?

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: No , no , we would not !

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: You will go to punish the foes of your kings ?

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: We will go .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: And what will be your reward ? Know you not that victory will be yours , because the god is with you . And if some fall in battle , should we not all envy their fate , since they leave this world to go towards Osiris . The arrows of your foes will fall harmless at your feet , like wounded birds . Their swords shall bend on your invulnerable bodies . The fire they light against you will become as perfumed water . All this you know to be true . You know that your gods protect you . You know they are all-powerful , because , yesterday , you all did see how the stone image of the goddess Isis did bow , to show you she protects you .

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: To the war ! To the war ! To Ethiopia ! SATNIleaping up to the terraceI have been coward too long !To the crowdThe miracle of yesterday — ‘ twas I — ‘ twas I who worked it . General uproar .

sp.speaker: HIGH PRIEST
sp.p: I deliver this man to you , and I deliver you to him . You will not let him deceive you twice . Execrations of the people , Satni cannot speak . The High Priest is borne out on his throne accompanied by Rheou . SATNIwhen the uproar subsidesI was in the temple —

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: That is a lie !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: It was I who made the head of the image bow .

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: He blasphemes . Have done ! Have done ! Let him not blaspheme !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: It was I ! And I ask your forgiveness .

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: Why should you do it , if you despise our gods ?

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: I did it out of pity .

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: We have no need of your pity .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: That is true . You have need only of my courage . And I failed you . I was touched by your tears . I was weak , thinking to be kind .

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: You are not kind . You would have handed us over to foreign gods .

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: Yes ! yes ! that is true !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: I gave you the lie that you begged for . I wanted to lull your sorrows to sleep .

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: You have brought down on us the anger of the gods .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: The evils that crush us , ‘ tis you have let them loose on us .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Yes , yes ! Liar ! Curse you ! Let him be accursed !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Curse me . You are right . I am guilty . I had not the strength to persevere ; to lead you , in spite of your tears , to the summits I would lead you to . To still a few sobs , to give hope to some who were stricken , I worked the miracle ; and , beholding that false miracle , you made submission . I have confirmed , I have strengthened the empire of the lie .

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: ‘ Twas you who lied .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: I have given back your minds , for another age , to slavery and debasement . I have given back to the priests their power that was endangered . I have given them means to increase your burdens , to take your daughters , to send you to a war , covetous , murderous , and unjust .

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: You are a spy from Ethiopia !

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: You are a traitor to your country !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Yes ! a traitor ! Death to the traitor !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: And to defend your tyrants , you will kill men as wretched as yourselves , dupes like you , and like you enslaved .

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: We know you are paid to betray Egypt !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Yes , we know it ! We know the price of your treason !

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: You would sell Egypt , and ‘ tis to weaken us you would overthrow our gods .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Traitor ! Traitor !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: If I am a traitor , ‘ tis to my own cause ! But a while ago I was proud of my deed , thinking I had sacrificed myself to you . Alas ! I only sacrificed your future to my pity . I wept for you ; to weep for misfortune — what is that but an easy escape from the duty of fighting its cause ? I pitied you . Pity is but a weakness , a submission — To perpetuate the falsehood of the miracle , and the life of atonement to come is to drug misery to sleep .

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: Misery !— can you give us anything to cure it ? They laugh .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: They have implanted in you , the belief that misery is immortal , invincible . By my falsehood , I too have seemed to admit this ; and thus I have helped those , in whose interest it is that misery should last for ever .

sp.speaker: A MAN
sp.p: He insults the Pharaoh !

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: Do not insult our priests !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Had there been no miracle , you would have despaired — you would have sorrowed . I ought to have faced that . I ought to have faced the death of a few , to save the future of all . We go forward only by destroying . What matter blood and pain ! Pain and blood — never a child is born without them ! I would — An angry outburst .

sp.speaker: A WOMAN
sp.p: Kill him ! Kill him ! He says we must put our children to death !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: All are glorious who preach new efforts —

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: Death ! Death to the traitor !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: All are infamous who preach resignation —

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: Enough ! Kill him ! Death !

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: It is in this world that the wretched must find their paradise , it is here that every one 's good must be sought with a zeal that knows no limit , save respect for the good of others . A burst of laughter .

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: He is mad ! He knows not what he says ! He is mad ! Yaouma is borne on right on a litter carried by young girls . She is decked out like an idol ; she stands erect , half in ecstasy .

sp.speaker: PEOPLE
sp.p: Yaouma ! The chosen of Ammon-Ra ! Glory to her who goes to save Egypt ! With jubilant cries the procession goes slowly towards the gates at the back , preceded and surrounded by musicians and dancers .

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: Yaouma ! Yaouma ! One word ! One look of farewell ! Yaouma ! ‘ Tis I , Satni ! Look on me ! The acclamations drown his voice . Yaouma is wrapped in her soul 's dream . She passes without hearing Satni 's voice . The crowd follows her . MIERISto Delethi who supports herLead me to Satni — go —To SatniSatni , your words have sunk deep in my heart — Yaouma , they tell me , did not hear your voice . She is lost in the joy of sacrifice . The need to make sacrifice is in us all . If the gods are not , to whom shall we sacrifice ourselves ?

sp.speaker: SATNI
sp.p: To those who suffer .

sp.speaker: MIERIS
sp.p: To those who suffer . During this Bitiou has come slowly down behind Satni .

sp.speaker: BITIOU
sp.p: Look ! He too , he will fall down ! He plunges a dagger in Satni 's back . Delethi draws Mieris away . Satni falls . SATNIraising himself slightlyIt was you who struck me , Bitiou —He looks long and sadly at himI pity you with all my heart — with all my heart .He diesBitiou looks at the blood on the dagger , and flings it away in horror . Then he crouches down by Satni and begins to cry softly . DELETHIto MierisMistress , come and pray !

sp.speaker: MIERIS
sp.p: No , I do not believe in gods in whose name men kill . Outside are heard the trumpets and acclamations that accompany Yaouma to the Nile .

div.stage: CURTAIN

div.head: SCENE I :— A small reception-room in an old house at

stage.stage: Mauleon .
The curtain rises , revealing Madame Vagret in evening dress ; she is altering the position of the chairs to her own satisfaction . Enter Bertha , also in evening dress , a newspaper in her hand .

lg.l: Here 's the local paper , the Journal . I sent the Official
Gazette to father ; he has just come home from the Court . He 's dressing .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Is the sitting over ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: No , not yet . MADAME VAGRETtaking the newspaperAre they still discussing the case ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: As usual .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: One does n't need to search long . There 's a big head-line at the top of the page : “ The Irissary Murder . ” They 're attacking your father now !She reads“ Monsieur Vagret , our District Attorney . ”She continues to read to herselfAnd there are sub-headings too : “ The murderer still at large . ” As if that was our fault ! “ Justice asleep ! ” Justice asleep indeed ! How can they say such things when your father has n't closed his eyes for a fortnight ! Can they complain that he has n't done his duty ? Or that Monsieur Delorme , the examining magistrate , is n't doing his ? He has made himself quite ill , poor man ! Only the day before yesterday he had a tramp arrested because his movements were ever so little suspicious ! So you see ! No ! I tell you these journalists are crazy !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: It seems they are going to have an article in the Basque paper too .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: The Eskual Herria !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: So the chemist told me .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: I do n't care a sou for that . The Attorney-General does n't read it .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: On the contrary , father was saying the other day that the Attorney-General has translations sent him of every article dealing with the magistracy .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: The Attorney-General has translations sent him ! Oh well , never mind . Anyhow , let 's change the subject ! How many shall we be this evening ? You 've got the list ? BERTHAShe takes the list from the over-mantelThe President of Assizes — the President of the Court —

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Yes . Yes , that 's all right ; nine in all , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Nine .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Nine ! To have nine people coming to dinner , and not to know the exact hour at which they 'll arrive ! That 's what 's so trying about these dinners we have to give at the end of a session — in honor of the President of Assizes . One dines when the Court rises . When the Court rises ! Well , we 'll await the good pleasure of these gentlemen !She sighsWell , child !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Mother ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Are you still anxious to marry a magistrate ? BERTHAwith convictionI am not !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: But you were two years ago !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: I am not now !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Look at us ! There 's your father . Procurator of the Republic — Public Prosecutor — State Attorney ; in a court of the third class , it 's true , because he 's not a wire-puller , because he has n't played the political game . And yet he 's a valuable man — no one can deny that . Since he 's been District Attorney he has secured three sentences of penal servitude for life ! And in a country like this , where crimes are so frightfully rare ! That 's pretty good , do n't you think ? Of course , I know he 'll have had three acquittals in the session that ends to-day . Granted . But that was mere bad luck . And for protecting society as he does — what do they pay him ? Have you any idea ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Yes , I know ; you 've often told me , mother .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: And I 'll tell you again . Counting the stoppages for the pension , he gets altogether , and for everything , three hundred and ninety-five francs and eighty-three centimes a month . And then we are obliged to give a dinner for nine persons in honor of the President of Assizes , a Councillor ! Well , at all events , I suppose everything is ready ? Let 's see . My Revue des Deux Mondes — is it there ? Yes . And my armchair — is that in the right place ?She sits in itYes .As though receiving a guestPray be seated , Monsieur le Président . I hope that 's right . And Monsieur Dufour , who was an ordinary magistrate when your father was the same , when we were living at Castelnaudery , he 's now President of the second class at Douai , and he was only at Brest before he was promoted !

lg.stage: searching for a book on the over-mantel

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: I 'll take your word for it .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: You may ! The Judicial Year Book . I know it by heart !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: But then father may be appointed Councillor any day now .

lg.l: He 's been waiting a long time for his appointment as

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: But it 's as good as settled now . He was promised the first vacancy , and Monsieur Lefévre has just died .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: I hope to God you are right . If we fail this time , we 're done for . We shall be left at Mauleon until he 's pensioned off . What a misfortune it is that they can n't put their hands on that wretched murderer ! Such a beautiful crime too ! We really had some reason for hoping for a death sentence this time ! The first , remember !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Do n't worry , motherkins . There 's still a chance .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: It 's easy for you to talk . You see the newspapers are beginning to grumble . They reproach us , they say we are slack . My dear child , you do n't realize — there ‘ s a question of sending a detective down from Paris ! It would be such a disgrace ! And everything promised so well ! You can n't imagine how excited your father was when they waked him up to tell him that an old man of eighty-seven had been murdered in his district ! He dressed himself in less than five minutes . He was very quiet about it . But he gripped my hands . “ I think , ” he said , “ I think we can count on my nomination this time ! ”She sighsAnd now everything is spoilt , and all through this ruffian who wo n't let them arrest him !Another sighWhat 's the time ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: It has just struck six .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Write out the menus . Do n't forget . You must write only their titles — his Honor the President of Assizes , his Honor the President of the High Court of Mauleon , and so forth . It 's the preamble to the menu . Do n't forget . Here is your father . Go and take a look round the kitchen and appear as if you were busy .Bertha leaves the room . Vagret enters in evening dress

div.head: SCENE II :— Vagret , Madame Vagret .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Has n't the Court risen yet ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: When I left my substitute was just getting up to ask for the adjournment .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Nothing new ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: About the murder ? Nothing .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: But your Monsieur Delorme — the examining magistrate — is he really looking for the murderer ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: He 's doing what he can .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Well , if I were in his place , it seems to me — Oh , they ought to have women for examining magistrates !DistractedlyIs there nothing in the Official Gazette ? VAGRETdispirited and anxiousYes .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: And you never told me . Anything that affects us ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: No . Nanteuil has been appointed Advocate-General .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Nanteuil ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes .

lg.l: Oh , that 's too bad ! Why , he was only an assistant at
Lunéville when you were substitute there !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes . But he has a cousin who 's a deputy . You can n't compete with men like that .A pause . Madame Vagret sits down and begins to cry

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: We have n't a chance .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: My dearest ! Come , come , you are wrong there . MADAME VAGRETstill tearfulMy poor darling ! I know very well it is n't your fault ; you do your best . Your only failing is that you are too scrupulous , and I am not the one to reproach you for that . But what can you expect ? It 's no use talking ; everybody gets ahead of us . Soon you 'll be the oldest District Attorney in France .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Come , come ! Where 's the Year Book ? MADAME VAGRETstill in the same toneIt 's there — the dates , the length of service . See further on , dear . VAGRETthrowing the Year Book asideDo n't cry like that ! Remember I 'm chosen to succeed Lefévre .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: I know that .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I 'm on the list for promotion .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: So is everybody .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: And I have the Attorney-General 's definite promise — and the presiding judge 's too .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: It 's the deputy 's promise you ought to have .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Yes , the deputy 's . Up to now you 've waited for promotion to come to you . My dear , you 've got to run after it ! If you do n't do as the others do , you 'll simply get left behind .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I am still an honest man .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: It is because you are an honest man that you ought to try to get a better appointment . If the able and independent magistrates allow the others to pass them by , what will become of the magistracy ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: There 's some truth in what you say .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: If , while remaining scrupulously honest , you can better our position by getting a deputy to push you , you are to blame if you do n't do so . After all , what do they ask you to do ? Merely that you should support the Ministry .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I can do that honestly . Its opinions are my own .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Then you 'd better make haste — for a ministry does n't last long ! To support the Ministry is to support the Government — that is , the State — that is , Society . It 's to do your duty .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: You are ambitious .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: No , my dear — but we must think of the future . If you knew the trouble I have to make both ends meet ! We ought to get Bertha married . And the boys will cost us more and more as time goes on . And in our position we are bound to incur certain useless expenses which we could very well do without ; but we have to keep up appearances ; we have to “ keep up our position . ” We want Georges to enter the Polytechnique , and that 'll cost a lot of money . And Henri , if he 's going to study law — you 'd be able to help him on all the better if you held a better position . VAGRETafter a brief silenceI have n't told you everything .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: What is it ? VAGRETtimidlyCortan has been appointed Councillor at Amiens . MADAME VAGRETexasperatedCortan ! That idiot of a Cortan ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: This is too much !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: What can you expect ? The new Keeper of the Seals is in his department . You can n't fight against that !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: There 's always something — Cortan ! Wo n't she be making a show of herself — Madame Cortan — who spells “ indictment ” i-n-d-i-t-e ? She 'll be showing off her yellow hat ! Do n't you remember her famous yellow hat ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: It 's her husband who ought to wear that color !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Rosa , that 's unjust . MADAME VAGRETpainfully excitedI know it — but it does me good !

div.stage: Enter Catialéna .
CATIALÉNA . Madame , where shall I put the parcel we took from the linen-closet this morning ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: What parcel ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . The parcel — you know , Madame — when we were arranging the things in the linen-closet . MADAME VAGRET [ suddenly ] Oh — yes , yes . Take it to my room .
CATIALÉNA . Where shall I put it there ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Oh well , put it down here . I will put it away myself .

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . Very good , Madame . [ She leaves the room ] MADAME VAGRET [ snipping at the parcel and speaking to herself ] It 's no use stuffing it with moth-balls — it 'll all be moth-eaten before ever you wear it .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: What is it ? MADAME VAGRETplacing the parcel on the table and opening the wrapperLook !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Ah , yes — my red robe — the one you bought for me — in advance — two years ago .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Yes . That time it was Gamard who was appointed instead of you .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: What could you expect ? Gamard had a deputy for his brother-in-law ; there 's no getting over that . The Ministry has to assure itself of a majority .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: And to think that in spite of all my searching I have n't been able to discover so much as a municipal councillor among our relations !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Well — hide this thing . It torments me .He returns the gown , which he had unfolded , to his wifeIn any case I dare say it would n't fit me now .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Oh , they fit anybody , these things !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Let 's see —He takes off his coat

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: And it means a thousand francs more a year !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: It is n't faded .At this moment Bertha enters . Vagret hides the red gownWhat is it ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: It 's only me .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: You startled me . BERTHAcatching sight of the gownYou 've been appointed ! You 've been appointed !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Do be quiet ! Turn the key in the door !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Papa has been appointed !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Do as you 're told ! No , he has n't been appointed .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: It 's really as good as new .He slips it on

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Well , I should hope so ! I took care to get the very best silk .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Ah , if I could only wear this on my back when I 'm demanding the conviction of the Irissary murderer ! Say what you like , the man who devised this costume was no fool ! It 's this sort of thing that impresses the jury . And the prisoner too ! I 've seen him unable to tear his eyes from the gown of the State Attorney ! And you feel a stronger man when you wear it . It gives one a better presence , and one 's gestures are more dignified : “ Gentlemen of the court , gentlemen of the jury ! ” Could n't I make an impressive indictment ? “ Gentlemen of the court , gentlemen of the jury ! In the name of society , of which I am the avenging voice — in the name of the sacred interests of humanity — in the name of the eternal principles of morality — fortified by the consciousness of my duty and my right — I rise —He repeats his gestureI rise to demand the head of the wretched man who stands before you ! ”

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: How well you speak ! Vagret , with a shrug of the shoulders and a sigh , slowly and silently removes the gown and hands it to his wife .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Here — put it away .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: There 's the bell .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Yes . MADAME VAGRETto her daughterTake it .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Yes , mother .She makes a parcel of the gown and is about to leave the room

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Bertha !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Yes , mother ! MADAME VAGRETtearfullyPut some more moth-balls in it — poor child ! Bertha goes out . Catialéna enters .

div.head: SCENE III :— Vagret , Madame Vagret , Catialéna .

stage.stage: CATIALÉNA [ holding out an envelope ] This has just come for you , sir . [ She goes out again ]

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: What 's this ? The Basque paper — the Eskual Herria — an article marked with blue pencil .He reads“ Eskual herri guzia hamabartz egun huntan — ” How 's one to make head or tail of such a barbarian language ! MADAME VAGRETreading over his shoulderIt 's about you —

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Yes . There ! “ Vagret procuradoreak galdegin — ” Wait a minute .Calling through the further doorwayCatialéna ! Catialéna !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Catialéna will translate it for us .To Catialéna , who has enteredHere , Catialéna , just read this bit for us , will you ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . Why , yes , Madame . [ She reads ] “ Eta gaitzegilia ozda oraino gakpoian Irrysaryko . ”

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: And what does that mean ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . That means — they have n't arrested the Irissary murderer yet .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: We know that . And then ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . “ Baginakien yadanik dona Mauleano tribunala yuye arin edo tzarrenda berechiazela . ” That means there are no magistrates at Mauleon except those they 've got rid of from other places , and who do n't know their business — empty heads they 've got .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Thanks — that 's enough .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: No , no ! Go on , Catialéna !

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . “ Yaun hoyen Biribi — ”

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Biribi ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . Yes , Madame .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Well , what does Biribi mean in Basque ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . I do n't know .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: What ? You do n't know ? You mean you do n't want to say ? Is it a bad word ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . Oh no , Madame , I should know it then .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Biribi —

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Perhaps it 's a nickname they give you .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Perhaps that 's it .A pauseWell ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . They 're speaking of the master . MADAME VAGRET [ to her husband ] I told you so . [ To Catialéna ] Abusing him ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I tell you that 's enough !He snatches the paper from Catialéna and puts it in his pocketGo back to the kitchen . Hurry now — quicker than that !

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . Well , sir , I swear I wo n't tell you the rest of it .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: No one 's asking you to . Be off .

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . I knew the master would be angry . [ She turns to go

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Catialéna !

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . Yes , Madame ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Really now , you do n't know what Biribi means ?

div.stage: CATIALÉNA . No , Madame , I swear I do n't .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: That 's all right . There 's the bell — go and see who it is .Catialéna goesI shall give that woman a week 's notice , and no later than to-morrow .

lg.l: If you please , sir , it 's Monsieur Delorme .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Your examining magistrate ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes . He 's come to give me his reply .To CatialénaShow him in .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: What reply ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: He has come to return me his brief .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: The brief ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes . I asked him to think it over until this evening .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: He 'll have to stay to dinner .

lg.l: No . You know perfectly well his health — Here he is . Run away .

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Madame !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Well , my dear fellow , what is it ?

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Well , it 's no — positively no .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: I 've told you .A pause

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: And the alibi of your accused ?

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: I 've verified it .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Does it hold water ?

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Incontestably . VAGRETdejectedlyThen you 've set your man at liberty ? DELORMEregretfullyI simply had to . VAGRETthe sameObviously .A pauseThere is not a chance ?

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Well , then ?

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Well , I beg you to give the brief to someone else .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Is that final ?

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Yes . You see , my dear fellow , I 'm too old to adapt myself to the customs of the day . I 'm a magistrate of the old school , just as you are . I inherited from my father certain scruples which are no longer the fashion . These daily attacks in the press get on my nerves .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: They would cease at the news of an arrest .

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Precisely . I should end by doing something foolish . Well , I have done something foolish already . I should not have arrested that man if I had not been badgered as I was .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: He was a tramp . You gave him shelter for a few days . There 's no great harm done there .

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: All the same —

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: You let yourself be too easily discouraged . To-night or to-morrow something may turn up to put you on a new scent .

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Even then — Do you know what they are saying ? They are saying that Maître Plaçat , the Bordeaux advocate , is coming to defend the prisoner .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I do n't see what he has to gain by that .

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: He wants to come forward at the next election in our arrondissement — and he counts on attacking certain persons in his plea , so as to gain a little popularity .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: How can that affect you ?

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Why , he can be present at all the interrogations of the accused . The law allows it — and as he is ravenous for publicity , he would tell the newspapers just what he pleased , and if my proceedings did n't suit him , I 'd be vilified in the papers day after day .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: You are exaggerating .

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: I 'm not . Nowadays an examination takes place in the market-place or the editorial offices of the newspapers rather than in the magistrate 's office .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: That is true where notorious criminals are concerned . In reality the new law benefits them and them only — you know as well as I do that for the general run of accused persons —

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Seriously , I beg you to take the brief back .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Come ! You can n't imagine that Maître Plaçat , who has a hundred cases to plead , can be present at all your interrogations . You know what usually happens . He 'll send some little secretary — if he sends anyone .

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: I beg you not to insist , my dear Vagret . My decision is irrevocable .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Then —

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Allow me to take my leave . I do n't want to meet my colleagues who are dining with you .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Then I 'll see you to-morrow . I 'm sorry —

sp.speaker: DELORME
sp.p: Good-night . He goes out . Madame Vagret at once enters by another door .

div.head: SCENE V :— Vagret , Madame Vagret , then Bertha , Bunerat , La Bouzole ,

stage.stage: Mouzon .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Well , I heard — he gave you back the brief .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes — his health — the newspapers —

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: And now ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Be careful . No one suspects anything yet .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Make your mind easy .She listensThis time it is our guests .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: enteringHere they are .

lg.l: To your work , Bertha ! And for me the Revue des Deux

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: They are a long time .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: It 's Madame Bunerat . Her manners always take time .

sp.speaker: THE MANSERVANT
sp.p: His Honor the President of the Court and Madame Bunerat .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: How do you do , dear Madame Bunerat ?They exchange greetings

sp.speaker: THE MANSERVANT
sp.p: His Honor Judge La Bouzole . His worship Judge Mouzon . Salutations ; the guests seat themselves . MADAME VAGRETto Madame BuneratWell , Madame , so another session 's finished !

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: Yes , at last !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Your husband , I imagine , is not sorry .

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: Nor yours , I 'm sure .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: And the President of Assizes ?

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: He will be a little late . He wants to get away early to-morrow morning , and he has a mass of documents to sign . You must remember the Court has barely risen . When we saw that we should be sitting so late we sent for our evening clothes , and we changed while the jury was deliberating ; then we put our robes on over them to pronounce sentence .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: And the sentence was ?

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: An acquittal .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Again ! Oh , the juries are crazy !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: My dear , you express yourself just a little freely .

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: Now , my dear Madame Vagret , you must n't worry yourself . She leads her up the stage . BUNERATto VagretYes , my dear colleague , an acquittal . That makes three this session . MOUZONa man of forty , whiskered and foppishThree prisoners whom we have had to set at liberty because we could n't hold them for other causes .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: A regular run on the black ! LA BOUZOLEa man of seventyMy dear colleagues would prefer a run on the red .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: La Bouzole , you are a cynic ! I do not understand how you can have the courage to joke on such a subject .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: I should n't joke if your prisoners were condemned .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I 'm not thinking of our prisoners — I 'm thinking of ourselves . If you imagine we shall receive the congratulations of the Chancellery , you are mistaken .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: He does n't care a straw if the Mauleon Court does earn a black mark in Paris .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: You have said it , Bunerat ; I do n't care a straw ! I have nothing more to look for . I shall be seventy years old next week , and I retire automatically . Nothing more to hope for ; I have a right to judge matters according to my own conscience . I 'm out of school !He gives a little skipDo n't get your backs up — I 've done — I see the Year Book over there ; I 'm going to look out the dates of the coming vacation for you .He takes a seat to the left

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Well , there it is .To VagretThe President of Assizes is furious .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It wo n't do him any good either .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: And my substitute ?

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: You may well say “ your substitute ” !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It 's all his fault . He pleaded extenuating circumstances . He !

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Where does the idiot hail from ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: He 's far from being an idiot , I assure you . He was secretary to the Conference in Paris ; he is a doctor of laws and full of talent .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Talent !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I assure you he has a real talent for speaking .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: So we observed .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: He 's a very distinguished young fellow . BUNERATwith emphasisWell ! When a man has such talent as that he becomes an advocate ; he does n't enter the magistracy . MADAME VAGRETto La Bouzole , who approaches herSo really , Monsieur La Bouzole , it seems it 's the fault of the new substitute .

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: Tell us all about it .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: It was like this .He turns towards the ladies and continues in a low tone . Bertha , who has entered the room , joins the group , of which Vagret also forms oneMOUZONto BuneratAll this wo n't hasten our poor Vagret 's nomination . BUNERATsmilingThe fact is he has n't a chance at the present moment , poor chap !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Is it true that they were really seriously thinking of him when there is a certain other magistrate in the same court ? BUNERATwith false modestyI do n't think I — Of whom are you speaking ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Of yourself , my dear President .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: They have indeed mentioned my name at the Ministry .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: When you preside at Assizes the proceedings will be far more interesting than they are at present .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Now how can you tell that , my dear Mouzon ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Because I have seen you preside over the Correctional Court .He laughs

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Why do you laugh ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I just remembered that witty remark of yours the other day . BUNERATdelightedI do n't recall it .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It really was very witty !He laughs

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: What was it ? Did I say anything witty ? I do n't remember .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Anything ? A dozen things — a score . You were in form that day ! What a figure he cut — the prisoner . You know , the fellow who was so badly dressed . Cock his name was .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Ah , yes ! When I said : “ Cock , turn yourself on and let your confession trickle out ! ” MOUZONlaughingThat was it ! That was it ! And the witness for the defence — that idiot . Did n't you make him look a fool ? He could n't finish his evidence , they laughed so when you said : “ If you wish to conduct the case , only say so . Perhaps you 'd like to take my place ? ”

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Ah , yes ! Ladies , my good friend here reminds me of a rather amusing anecdote . The other day — it was in the Correctional Court — THE MANSERVANTannouncingMonsieur Gabriel Ardeuil .

div.head: SCENE VI :— The same , with Ardeuil .

stage.stage: ARDEUIL [ to Madame Vagret ] I hope you 'll forgive me for coming so late . I was detained until now .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: I will forgive you all the more readily since I 'm told you have had such a success to-day as will make all the advocates of the district jealous of you . Ardeuil is left to himself . LA BOUZOLEtouching him on the shoulderYoung man — come , sit down by me — as a favor . Do you realize that it wo n't take many trials like to-day 's to get you struck off the rolls ?

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: I could n't be struck off the rolls because —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Hang it all — a man does himself no good by appearing singular .

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: Singular ! But you yourself — Well , the deliberations are secret , but for all that I know you stand for independence and goodness of heart in this Court .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Yes , I 've permitted myself that luxury — lately .

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: Lately ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Yes , yes , my young friend , for some little time . Because for some little time I 've been cured of the disease which turns so many honest fellows into bad magistrates . That disease is the fever of promotion . Look at those men there . If they were n't infected by this microbe , they would be just , kindly gentlemen , instead of cruel and servile magistrates .

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: You exaggerate , sir . The French magistracy is not —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: It is not venal — that 's the truth . Among our four thousand magistrates you might perhaps not find one — you hear me , not one — even among the poorest and most obscure — who would accept a money bribe in order to modify his judgment . That is the glory of our country 's magistracy and its special virtue . But a great number of our magistrates are ready to be complaisant — even to give way — when it is a question of making themselves agreeable to an influential elector , or to the deputy , or to the minister who distributes appointments and favors . Universal suffrage is the god and the tyrant of the magistrate . So you are right — and I am not wrong .

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: Nothing can deprive us of our independence .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: That is so . But , as Monsieur de Tocqueville once remarked , we can offer it up as a sacrifice .

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: You are a misanthrope . There are magistrates whom no promise of any kind —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Yes , there are . Those who are not needy or who have no ambitions . Yes , there are obscure persons who devote their whole lives to their professions and who never ask for anything for themselves . But you can take my word for it that they are the exceptions , and that our Court of Mauleon , which you yourself have seen , represents about the average of our judicial morality . I exaggerate , you think ? Well ! Let us suppose that in all France there are only fifty Courts like this . Suppose there are only twenty — suppose there is only one . It is still one too many ! Why , my young friend , what sort of an idea have you got of the magistracy ?

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: It frightens me .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: You are speaking seriously ?

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Then why did you become a substitute ?

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: Through no choice of my own ! My people pushed me into the profession .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Yes . People look on the magistracy as a career . That is to say , from the moment you enter it you have only one object — to get on .A pause

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: Yet it would be a noble thing — to dispense justice tempered with mercy .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Yes — it should be .A pauseDo you want the advice of a man who has for forty years been a judge of the third class ?

sp.speaker: ARDEUIL
sp.p: I should value it .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Send in your resignation . You have mistaken your vocation . You wear the wrong robe . The man who attempts to put into practice the ideas you have expressed must wear the priest 's cassock . ARDEUILas though to himselfYes — but for that one must have a simple heart — a heart open to faith . BUNERATwho is with the othersIf only we had the luck to have a deputy of the department for Keeper of the Seals ! Just for a week ! LA BOUZOLEto ArdeuilThere , my boy , that 's the sort of thing one has to think about . THE MANSERVANTenteringFrom his Honor the President of Assizes .He gives Vagret a letter

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: He is n't coming ? MADAME VAGRETafter reading the noteHe is n't coming .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: I hardly expected him .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: A nervous headache he says . He left by the 6 : 49 train .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That 's significant !

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: It would be impossible to mark his disapproval more clearly .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Three acquittals too !

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: If it had been a question of celebrated pleaders ! But newly fledged advocates !

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Nobodies ! MADAME VAGRETto her daughterMy poor child ! What will his report be like ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: What report ?

lg.l: Do n't you know ? At the close of each session the
President submits a report to the Minister — Ah , my dear Madame Bunerat !
lg.stage: The three women seat themselves at the back of the stage

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Three acquittals — and the Irissary murder . A deplorable record ! A pretty pickle we 're in .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: You know , my dear Vagret , I 'm a plain speaker . No shilly-shallying about me . When I hunt the boar I charge right down on him . I speak plainly — anyone can know what 's in my mind . I 'm the son of a peasant , I am , and I make no bones about it . Well , it seems to me that your Bar — I know , of course , that you lead it with distinguished integrity and honesty — but it seems to me — how shall I put it ?— that it 's getting weak . Mouzon , you will remember , said the same thing when he was consulting the statistics .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It really is a very bad year .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: You know it was a question of making ourselves an exception to the general rule — of getting our Court raised to a higher class . Well , Mauleon wo n't be raised from the third class to the second if the number of causes diminishes .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: We should have to prove that we had been extremely busy .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: And many of the cases you settled by arrangement might well have been the subject of proceedings .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Just reflect that this year we have awarded a hundred and eighteen years less imprisonment than we did last year !

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: And yet the Court has not been to blame . We safeguard the interests of society with the greatest vigilance .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: But before we can punish you must give us prisoners .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I have recently issued the strictest orders respecting the repression of smuggling offences , which are so common in these parts .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Well , that 's something . You understand the point of view we take . It 's a question of the safety of the public , my dear fellow .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: We are falling behind other Courts of the same class . See , I 've worked out the figures .He takes a paper from his pocket-book and accidentally drops other papers , which La Bouzole picks upI see —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: You are dropping your papers , Mouzon . Is this yours — this envelope ?He reads“ Monsieur Benoît , Officer of the Navy , Railway Hotel , Bordeaux . ” A nice scent — MOUZONflurried , taking the letter from La BouzoleYes — a letter belonging to a friend of mine .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: And this ? The Irissary murder ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Ah , yes — it 's — I was going to explain — it 's — oh , the Irissary murder , yes — it 's the translation Bunerat gave me of the article which appeared in the Eskual Herria to-day . It is extremely unpleasant . They say Mauleon is a sort of penal Court — something like a Biribi of the magistracy .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: But , after all , I can n't invent a murderer for you just because the fellow is so pig-headed that he wo n't allow himself to be taken ! Delorme has sent the description they gave us to the offices of all the magistrates .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Delorme ! Shall I tell you what I think ? Well , our colleague Delorme is making a mistake in sticking to the idea that the criminal is a tramp .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: But there is a witness .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: The witness is lying , or he 's mistaken .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: A witness who saw gipsies leaving the victim 's house that morning .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I repeat , the witness is lying , or he is mistaken .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Why so ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I 'm certain of it .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Because I 'm certain the murderer was n't a gipsy .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: But explain —

lg.l: It 's of no use , my dear friend . I know my duty to my colleague
Delorme too well to insist . I 've said too much already .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: By no means .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It was with the greatest delicacy that I warned our colleague Delorme — he was good enough to consult me and show me day by day the information which he had elicited — I warned him that he was on a false scent . He would listen to nothing ; he persisted in searching for his tramp . Well , let him search ! There are fifty thousand tramps in France . After all , I am probably wrong . Yet I should be surprised , for in the big towns in which I have served as magistrate , and in which I found myself confronted , not merely now and again , but every day , so to speak , with difficulties of this sort , I was able to acquire a certain practice in criminal cases and a certain degree of perspicacity .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Obviously . As for Delorme , it is the first time he has had to deal with such a big crime .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: In the case of that pretty woman from Toulouse , at Bordeaux , a case which made a good deal of stir at the time , it was I who forced the accused to make the confession that led her to the guillotine . BUNERATadmiringlyWas it really ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: My dear friend , I ask you most seriously — and if I am insistent , it is because I have reasons for being so — between ourselves , I beg you to tell us on what you base your opinion .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , I do n't want to hide my light under a bushel — I 'll tell you .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: We are listening .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Recall the facts . In a house isolated as are most of our Basque houses they find , one morning , an old man of eighty-seven murdered in his bed . Servants who slept in the adjacent building had heard nothing . The dogs did not bark . There was robbery , it is true , but the criminal did not confine himself to stealing hard cash ; he stole family papers as well . Remember that point . And I will call your attention to another detail . It had rained on the previous evening . In the garden footprints were discovered which were immediately attributed to the murderer , who was so badly shod that the big toe of his right foot protruded from his boot . Monsieur Delorme proceeds along the trail ; he obtains a piece of evidence that encourages him , and he declares that the murderer is a vagrant . I say this is a mistake . The murderer is not a vagrant . Now the house in which the crime was committed is an isolated house , and we know that within a radius of six to ten miles there was no tramp begging before the crime . So this tramp , if there was one , would have eaten and drunk on the scene of the crime , either before or after striking the blow . Now no traces have been discovered which permit us to suppose that he did anything of the kind . So — here is a man who arrives in a state of exhaustion . He begs ; he is refused . He then hides himself , and , when it is night , he robs and assassinates . There is wine and bread and other food at hand ; but he goes his way without touching them . Is this probable ? No . Do n't tell me that he was disturbed and so ran off ; it is not true ; their own witness declares that he saw him in the morning , a few yards from the house , whereas the crime was committed before midnight . If Monsieur Delorme , in addition to his distinguished qualities , had a little experience of cases of this kind , he would realize that empty bottles , dirty glasses , and scraps of food left on the table constitute , so to speak , the sign manual which the criminal vagrant leaves behind him on the scene of his crime .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: True ; I was familiar with that detail . LA BOUZOLEunder his breath to ArdeuilThat fellow would send a man to the scaffold for the sake of seeming to know something .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Go on — go on .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Monsieur Delorme ought to have known this also : in the life of the vagrant there is one necessity which comes next to hunger and thirst — it is the need of footwear . This is so true that they have sometimes been known to make this need a pretext for demanding an appeal , because the journey to the Court of Appeal is generally made on foot , so that the administration is obliged to furnish shoes , and , as these are scarcely worn during the period of detention , they are in good condition when the man leaves prison . Now the supposed vagrant has a foot very nearly the same size as that of his victim . He has — you yourself have told us — boots which are in a very bad condition . Well , gentlemen , this badly shod vagrant does not take the good strong boots which are in the house ! I will add but one word more .
