If the crime had been committed by a passing stranger — by a professional mendicant — will you tell me why this remarkable murderer follows the road which passes in front of the victim 's house — a road on which he would find no resources — a road on which houses are met with only at intervals of two or three miles — when there is , close at hand , another road which runs through various villages and passes numbers of farmhouses , in which it is a tradition never to refuse hospitality to one of his kind ? One word more . Why does this vagrant steal family papers which will betray him as the criminal the very first time he comes into contact with the police ? No , gentlemen , the criminal is not a vagrant . If you want to find him , you must not look for a man wandering along the highway ; you must look for him among those relatives or debtors or friends , who had an interest in his death .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: This is very true .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: I call that admirably logical and extremely lucid .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Believe me , the matter is quite simple . If I were intrusted with the examination , I guarantee that within three days the criminal would be under lock and key .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Well , my dear colleague , I have a piece of news for you . Monsieur Delorme , who is very unwell , has returned me his brief this afternoon , and it will be intrusted to you . Henceforth the preliminary examination of the Irissary murder will be in your hands .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I have only to say that I accept . My duty is to obey . I withdraw nothing of what I have said ; within three days the murderer will be arrested .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Bravo !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I thank you for that promise in the name of all concerned . I declare that you relieve us of a great anxiety .To his wifeListen , my dear . Monsieur Mouzon is undertaking the preliminary examination , and he promises us a result before three days are up .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: We shall be grateful , Monsieur Mouzon .

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: Oh , thank you !

lg.l: Bertha ! Tell them to serve dinner — and to send up that old
Irrouleguy wine ! I will drink to your success , my dear fellow .

sp.speaker: THE MANSERVANT
sp.p: Dinner is served . The gentlemen offer their arms to the ladies preparatory to going in to dinner .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: ACT II
div.stage: In the office of Mouzon , the examining magistrate . A door at the back and in the wall to the right . On the left are two desks . Portfolios , armchairs , and one ordinary chair .

div.head: SCENE I :— The recorder , then the doorkeeper , then Mouzon . When the

stage.stage: curtain rises the recorder , seated in the magistrate 's armchair , is drinking his coffee . The doorkeeper enters .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Ah ! Here 's our friend the doorkeeper of the courthouse ! Well , what 's the news ?

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: Here 's your boss .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Already !

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: He got back from Bordeaux last night . Fagged out he looked . RECORDERloftilyA Mauleon magistrate is always fatigued when he returns from Bordeaux !

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: Why ? RECORDERafter a pauseI do not know .

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: It 's the Irissary murder that has brought him here so early .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Probably .While speaking he arranges his cup , saucer , sugar basin , etc ., in a drawer . He then goes to his own place , the desk at the back . Mouzon enters . The doorkeeper pretends to have completed some errand and leaves the room . The recorder rises , with a low bowGood-morning , your worship .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Good-morning . You have n't made any engagements , have you , except in the case of the Irissary murder ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: I have cited the officer of the gendarmerie , the accused , and the wife of the accused .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I am tired , my good fellow . I have a nervous headache ! Any letters for me ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: No , your worship .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: His Honor the State Attorney has n't asked for me ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: No , your worship . But all the same I have something for you .He hands him an envelopeMOUZONopening the envelopeStamps for my collection ! I say , Benoît , that 's good ! Now let 's see . Let 's see .He unlocks the drawer of his desk and takes out a stamp albumUruguay . I have it ! Well , it will do to exchange . And this one too . Oh ! Oh ! I say , Benoît ! A George Albert , first edition ! But where did you get this , my dear fellow ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: A solicitor 's clerk found it in a brief .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Splendid ! I must stick that in at once ! Pass me the paste , will you ?He delicately trims the edges of the stamp with a pair of scissors and pastes it in the album with the greatest care , while still talkingIt is rare , extremely rare ! According to the Philatelist it will exchange for three blue Amadei or a ‘ 67 Khedive , obliterated . There !Turning over the leaves of his albumReally , you know , it begins to look something like . It 's beginning to fill up , eh ? You know I believe I shall soon be able to get that Hayti example . Look ! See here !In great delightThere 's a whole page-full ! And all splendid examples .He closes the album and sighsO Lord !

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: You do n't feel well ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It 's not that . I was rather worried at Bordeaux .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: About your stamps ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: No , no .A sigh to himselfDamn the women ! The very thing I did n't want .He takes his album againWhen I 've got that Hayti specimen I shall need only three more to fill this page too . Yes .He closes the albumWell , what 's the post ? Ah ! Here is the information from Paris in respect of the woman Etchepare and her husband 's judicial record .The doorkeeper enters with a visiting-cardWho is coming to disturb me now ?More agreeably , having read the nameAh ! Ah !To the recorderI shall see him alone .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your worship .He goes outMOUZONto the doorkeeperShow him in .He hides his album , picks up a brief , and affects to be reading it with the utmost attention

stage.stage: MONDOUBLEAU [ speaking with a strong provincial accent ] I was passing the Law Courts , and I thought I 'd look in and say how do . I am not disturbing you , I hope ?

MOUZON [ smiling and closing his brief ] My dear deputy , an examining magistrate , as you know , is always busy . But it gives one a rest — it does one good — to see a welcome caller once in a while . Sit down , I beg you . Yes , please !

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I can stop only a minute .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: But that 's unkind of you !

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Well , what 's the latest about the Irissary murder ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: So far there 's nothing new . I 've questioned the accused — an ugly-looking fellow and a poor defence . He simply denied everything and flew into a temper . I had to send him back to the cells without getting anything out of him .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Are you perfectly sure you 've got the right man ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Certain — no ; but I should be greatly surprised if I were mistaken .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I saw Monsieur Delorme yesterday . He 's a little better .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: So I hear . He thinks the murderer was a tramp . Now there , my dear sir , is one of the peculiarities to which we examining magistrates are subject . We always find it the very devil to abandon the first idea that pops into our minds . Personally I do my best to avoid what is really a professional failing . I am just going to examine Etchepare , and I am waiting for the results of a police inquiry . If all this gives me no result , I shall set the man at liberty and look elsewhere for the culprit — but I repeat , I firmly believe I am on the right scent .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Monsieur Delorme is a magistrate of long experience and a very shrewd one , and I will not deny that the reasons he has given me are —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I know my colleague is extremely intelligent . And , once more , I do n't say that he 's wrong . We shall see . At present I am only morally certain . I shall be materially certain when I know the antecedents of the accused and have established an obvious motive for his action . At the moment of your arrival I was about to open my mail . Here is a letter from the Court of Pau ; it gives our man 's judicial record .He takes a paper-knife in order to open the envelope

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: A curious paper-knife .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That ? It 's the blade of the knife that brought the pretty Toulouse woman to the guillotine at Bordeaux . Pretty weapon , eh ? I had it made into a paper-knife .He opens the envelopeThere — there you are ! Four times sentenced for assaulting and wounding . You see —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Really , really ! Four times !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: This is getting interesting . Besides this — I have neglected nothing — I have learned that his wife , Yanetta Etchepare —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Is that the young woman I saw in the corridor just now ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I have called her as witness . I shall be hearing her directly .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: She looks a very respectable woman .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Possibly . But , as I was about to tell you , I have learned that she used to live in Paris — before her marriage — I have written asking for information . Here we are .He opens the envelope and smilesAha ! Well , this young woman who looks so respectable was sentenced to one month 's imprisonment for receiving stolen goods . Now we will hear the police lieutenant who is coming , very obligingly , to give me an account of the inquiry with which I intrusted him , and which he will put in writing this evening . I shall soon see —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Do you suppose he will have anything new for you ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Does this interest you ? I will see him in your presence .He goes to the door and makes a sign . He returns to his chairUnderstand , I assert nothing . It is quite possible that my colleague 's judgment has been more correct than mine .The officer enters

div.head: SCENE III :— The same and the officer .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Good-morning , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Good-morning , lieutenant . You can speak before this gentleman . OFFICERsalutingOur deputy —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Yes ! He 's the man ! MOUZONafter a glance at MondoubleauDo n't let 's go too fast . On what grounds do you make that assertion ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: You will see . In the first place there have been four convictions already .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Then fifteen years ago he bought , from Daddy Goyetche , the victim , a vineyard , the payment taking the form of a life annuity .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well !

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: He professed to have made a very bad bargain , and he used to abuse old Goyetche as a swindler .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Excellent !

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Five years ago he sold this vineyard .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: So that for five years he has been paying an annuity to the victim , although the vineyard was no longer his property .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Yes , your worship .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Go on .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: After his arrest people 's tongues were loosened . His neighbors have been talking .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That 's always the way .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: I have heard a witness , the girl Gracieuse Mendione , to whom Etchepare used the words , “ It is really too stupid to be forced to pay money to that old swine . ”

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Wait a moment . You say the girl Gracieuse ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Mendione . MOUZONwritingMendione — “ It is really too stupid to be forced to pay money to that old swine . ” Good ! Good ! Well ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: I have another witness , Piarrech Artola . MOUZONwritingPiarrech Artola .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Etchepare told him , about two months ago , in speaking of old Goyetche , “ It 's more than one can stand — the Almighty 's forgotten him . ” MOUZONwriting“ The Almighty has forgotten him . ” Excellent . Is this all you can tell me ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Almost all .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: At what date should Etchepare have made the next annual payment to old Goyetche ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: A week after Ascension Day .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That is a week after the crime ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Yes , your worship . MOUZONto MondoubleauSingular coincidence !To the officerWas he comfortably off , this Etchepare ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: He was pressed for money . Three months ago he borrowed eight hundred francs from a Mauleon cattle-dealer .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: And what do the neighbors say ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: They say Etchepare was a sly grasping fellow , and they are n't surprised to hear that he 's the murderer . All the same , they all speak very highly of the woman Yanetta Etchepare . They say she is a model mother and housekeeper .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: How many children ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Two — Georges and — I can n't remember the name of the other now .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: And the woman 's moral character ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Irreproachable .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Good .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: I was forgetting . One of my men , one of those who effected the arrest , informs me that when Etchepare saw him coming he said to his wife , “ They 've got me . ”

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: “ They 've got me . ” That is rather important .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: And then he told his wife , in Basque , “ Do n't for the world let out that I left the house last night ! ”

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: He said this before the gendarme ?

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: No , your worship — the gendarme was outside — close to an open window . Etchepare did n't see him .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You will have him cited as witness .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Yes , your worship . Then there 's that witness for the defence too — Bridet .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Ah , yes — I have read the deposition he made in your presence . It 's of no importance . Still , if he 's there I 'll hear him . Thank you . Well , draw up a report for me , in full detail , and make them give you the summonses for the witnesses .

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.p: Yes , your worship .He salutes and goes out

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Monsieur Delorme is a fool . MOUZONlaughingWell , I do n't say so , my dear deputy .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: It 's wonderful , your faculty of divination .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Wonderful — no , no . I assure you —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Now how did you come to suspect this Etchepare ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , you know , it is partly a matter of temperament . The searching for a criminal is an art . I may say that a good examining magistrate is guided less by the facts themselves than by a kind of inspiration .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Wonderful . I repeat it 's wonderful . And this witness for the defence ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: He may be a false witness .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Because he accuses the gipsies ! Moreover , he had business dealings with Etchepare . The Basque , you know , still look on us rather as enemies , as conquerors , and they think it no crime to deceive us by means of a false oath .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Then you were never inclined to accept the theory of your predecessor ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Tramps — the poor wretches ! I know what an affection you have for the poor , and I feel with you that one should not confine oneself to suspecting the unfortunate — people without shelter , without bread even .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Bravo ! I am delighted to find that you are not only an able magistrate , but also that you think with me on political matters .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You are very good .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I hope that from now on the Basque newspapers will cease its attacks upon you .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I am afraid not .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Come , come !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: What can you expect , my dear sir ? The paper is hostile to you , and as I do not scruple openly to support your candidature they make the magistrate pay for the opinions of the citizen .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I feel ashamed — and I thank you with all my heart , my dear fellow . Go on as you are doing — but be prudent — eh ? The Keeper of the Seals was saying to me only a couple of days ago , “ I look to you to see that there is no trouble in your constituency . No trouble — above all no scandal of any kind ! ” I ought to tell you that Eugène is the subject of many attacks at the present moment .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You are on very intimate terms with his Honor the Keeper of the Seals . MONDOUBLEAUmakes a gesture , then , simplyWe were in the Commune together .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I see .

lg.l: Tell me , by the way , what sort of a man is your State

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Monsieur Vagret ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Oh , well — he 's a very painstaking magistrate , very exact —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: No , I mean as to his political opinions .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You must n't blame him for being in the political camp of those who are diametrically opposed to us . At all events , do n't run away with the idea that he is a mischievous person .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Narrow-minded .He has for some little time been gazing at Mouzon 's deskI see you 've got the Labastide brief on your table . There 's nothing in it at all . I know Labastide well ; he 's one of my ablest electoral agents ; and I assure you he 's absolutely incapable of committing the actions of which he is accused . I told Monsieur Vagret as much , but I see he is prosecuting after all .

lg.l: I can only assure you , my dear deputy , that I will give the
Labastide affair my most particular attention .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I have too much respect for you , my dear fellow , to ask more of you . Well , well , I must n't waste your time . So for the present —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Au revoir .The deputy goes out . Mouzon is aloneI do n't think our deputy is getting such a bad idea of me .SmilingThe fact is it was really clever of me to suspect Etchepare . Now the thing is to make him confess the whole business , and as quickly as possible — The doorkeeper enters , a telegram in his hand .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: A telegram for me ?

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: Yes , your honor .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Give it me . Right .The doorkeeper goes out . Mouzon reads“ Diane is detained under arrest . The report of yesterday 's affair sent to the Attorney-General .— Lucien . ” That 's nice for me !He is silent , pacing to and froOh , the accursed women !SilenceCome , I must get to work .He goes to the door at the back and calls his recorderBenoît !

div.head: SCENE V :— Mouzon , the recorder , and then Bridet .

stage.stage: MOUZON [ seated , gives a brief to the recorder ] Make out an order of non-lieu in the Labastide case and the order for his immediate release . You can do that during the interrogatories . Now , let us begin ! It is two o'clock already and we have done nothing . Make haste — Let 's see — What are you waiting for ? Give me the list of witnesses — the list of witnesses . Do n't you understand ? What 's the matter with you to-day ? That 's right . Now bring in this famous witness for the defence and let us get rid of him . Is Etchepare there ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your honor .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: His wife too ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your honor .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , then ! What 's the matter with you that you look at me like that ? Bring him in .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Which first ? Etchepare ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: No !— the witness for the defence . The wit-ness for the de-fence — do you understand ? RECORDERoutside , angrilyBridet ! Come , Bridet , are you deaf ? Come in !RoughlyStir yourself ! Bridet enters .

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Your worship , I am going to tell you —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Hold your tongue . You will speak when you are questioned . Name , surname , age , profession , and place of domicile .

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Bridet , Jean-Pierre , thirty-eight , maker of alpargates at Faigorry . MOUZONin a single breathYou swear to speak the truth , the whole truth , and nothing but the truth . Say , “ I swear . ” You are neither a blood relative nor a relation by marriage of the accused , you are not in his service and he is not in yours .To the recorderHas he said , “ I swear ” ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your worship . MOUZONto BridetSpeak !SilenceGo on — speak !

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: I am waiting for you to ask me questions .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Just now one could n't keep you quiet ; now when I ask you to speak you have nothing to say . What interest have you in defending Etchepare ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: What interest ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Yes . Do n't you understand your own language ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur . Why , no interest .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: No interest ? Is that the truth ? Eh ? None ? Come , I want very much to believe you .Very sternlyHowever , I remind you that Article 361 of the Penal Code punishes false evidence with imprisonment . Now that you know the risk you run in not telling the truth I will listen to you . BRIDETconfusedI was going to say that old Goyetche was murdered by gipsies who came from over the frontier , down the mountain .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You are sure of that ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: I believe it 's so .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You are not here to say what you believe . Tell me what you saw or heard . That is all that 's asked of you .

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: But one 's always meeting them , these gipsies . The other day they robbed a tobacconist 's shop . There were three of them . Two of them went inside . I must tell you they had looked the place over during the day —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Did you come here to laugh at the law ? Eh ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: I ?— But , Monsieur —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I ask if you came here to mock at the law ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: No , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That 's as well , for such a thing wo n't answer — you understand ? Do you hear ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Is that all you have to say ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: No , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , then , go on ! Confound it ! Do n't waste my time in this way ! Do you think I 've nothing to do but listen to your gossip ? Come now , tell me .

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Well , the day after Ascension Day — that is , on the Monday — no , on the Friday —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Was it Monday or Friday ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Friday — it was like a Monday , you see , because it was the day after the holiday . Well , the day they found old Goyetche murdered I saw a troop of gipsies leaving his house .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Then you were quite close to the house ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: No , I was passing on the road .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Did they close the door behind them ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: I do n't know , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Then why do you say you saw them come out of the house ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: I saw them come out of the meadow in front of the house .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: And then ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: That 's all . MOUZONthrowing himself back in his chairAnd you 've come here to bother me for this , eh ? Answer . For this ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: But , your worship — I beg your pardon — I thought — I beg your pardon —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Listen . How many gipsies were there ? Think well . Do n't make a mistake .

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Five .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Are you certain of that ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Yes . Well , in the presence of the gendarmes you said there were five or six . So you are more certain of a fact at the end of a month than you were on the day on which you observed it . On the other hand , you no longer know whether the fact occurred on a Monday or a Friday , nor whether the gipsies were leaving the house or merely crossing the fields .SternlyTell me , are you acquainted with the accused ? Etchepare — do you know him ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You have business relations with him ? You used to sell him sheep ?

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That 's enough for me . Get out !

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: And think yourself lucky that I let you go like this .

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: In future , before asking to be heard as a witness for the defence in a trial at law , I recommend you to think twice .

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Rest your mind easy , Monsieur . I swear they 'll never get me again !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Sign your interrogatory and be off . If there were not so many easy-going blunderers of your sort , there would be less occasion to complain of the law 's delays and hesitations for which the law itself is not responsible .

sp.speaker: BRIDET
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur . MOUZONto the recorderSend for Etchepare . RECORDERreturning immediatelyYour worship .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: The advocate — Maître Plaçat .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Is he there ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your honor . He would like to see you before the interrogatory .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , show him in , then ! What are you waiting for ? Be off — and come back when I send for the accused . The recorder goes out as Plaçat enters .

div.head: SCENE VI :— Mouzon , Maître Plaçat .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Good-day , my dear fellow — how are you ?

div.stage: PLAÇAT . Fine . And you ? I caught sight of you last night at the Grand Theatre ; you were with an extremely charming woman .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Ah , yes — I — er —

div.stage: PLAÇAT . I beg your pardon . Tell me now — I wanted to have a word with you about the Etchepare case .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: If you are free at the present moment , we are going to hold the examination at once .

div.stage: PLAÇAT . That 's the trouble — I have n't a minute .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Would you like us to postpone it until to-morrow ?

div.stage: PLAÇAT . No , no — I have just been speaking to the accused . An uninteresting story . He just keeps on denying — that 's all . He agreed to be interrogated without me . [ Laughing ] I wo n't hide from you that I advised him to persist in his method . Well , then , au revoir . If he wants an advocate later on , let me know — I 'll send you one of my secretaries .

lg.l: Right . Good-bye for the present , then .
He returns to his desk . The recorder enters , then

div.stage: SCENE VII :— Mouzon , Etchepare , the recorder .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Step forward . MOUZONto the recorderRecorder , write .Very quickly , stutteringIn the year nineteen hundred and ninety-seven , etc . Before me , Mouzon , examining magistrate , in the presence of — and so on — the Sieur Etchepare Jean-Pierre was brought to our office , his first appearance being recorded in the report of — and so on . We may mention that the accused , having consented to interrogation in the absence of his advocate —To EtchepareYou do consent , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I am innocent . I do n't need any advocate . MOUZONresumes his stutteringWe dispensed therewith . In consequence of which we have immediately proceeded as below to the interrogation of the said Sieur Etchepare Jean-Pierre .To EtchepareEtchepare , on the occasion of your first appearance you refused to reply , which was n't perhaps very sensible of you , but you were within your rights . You lost your temper and I was even obliged to remind you of the respect due to the law . Are you going to speak to-day ? ETCHEPAREdisturbedYes , your worship .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Ah ! Aha ! my fine fellow , you are not so proud to-day !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No . I 've been thinking . I want to get out of this as quickly as possible .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , well , for my part , I ask nothing more than to be able to set you at liberty . So far we understand each other excellently . Let us hope it 'll last . Sit down . And first of all I advise you to give up trying to father the crime onto a band of gipsies . The witness Bridet , who has business relations with you , has endeavored , no doubt at your instigation , to induce us to accept this fable . I warn you he has not succeeded .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I do n't know what Bridet may have told you .

lg.l: Oh ! You deny it ? So much the better ! Come , you are cleverer than
I thought ! Was it you who murdered Goyetche ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You had an interest in his death ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Oh , really ! I thought you had to pay him a life annuity . ETCHEPAREafter a moment 's hesitationYes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Then you had an interest in his death ?SilenceEh ! You do n't answer ? Well , let us continue . You said to a witness , the young woman — the young woman Gracieuse Mendione — “ It is really too stupid to be forced to pay money to that old swine . ” ETCHEPAREwithout convictionThat 's not true .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It 's not true ! So the witness is a liar , eh ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You do n't know .A pauseYou thought that Goyetche had lived too long ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: No , Monsieur . Then why did you say to another witness , Piarrech Artola , why did you say , in speaking of your creditor , “ It 's too much , the Almighty has forgotten him ” ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I did n't say that .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You did n't say that . So this witness is a liar too ! Answer me . Is he a liar ?SilenceYou do n't answer . It 's just as well . Come now , Etchepare , why do you persist in these denials — eh ? Is n't it all plain enough ? You are avaricious , interested , greedy for gain —

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: It 's so hard to make a living .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You are a man of violent temper — from time to time you get drunk , and then you become dangerous . You have been four times convicted for assault and wounding — you are over-ready with your knife . Is that the truth or is n't it ? You were tired of paying — for nothing — a biggish annual sum to this old man . The time for payment was approaching ; you were pressed for money ; you felt that Goyetche had lived too long , and you killed him . It 's so obvious — eh ? Is n't it true ? ETCHEPAREgradually recovering himselfI did not murder him .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: We wo n't juggle with words . Did you pay anyone else to kill him ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I had nothing to do with his death . You yourself say I was pressed for money . So how could I have paid anyone to kill him ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Then you did it yourself .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: That 's a lie .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Listen , Etchepare — you will confess sooner or later . Already you are weakening in your defence .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: If I was to shout , you 'd say I was play-acting .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I tell you sooner or later you will change your tune . Already you admit facts which constitute a serious charge against you .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: That 's true ; I said it without thinking of the consequences .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Ah , but you ought to think of the consequences ; for they may be peculiarly serious for you .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I 'm not afraid of death .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: The death of others —

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Nor my own .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: So much the better . But you are a Basque ; you are a Catholic . After death there is hell .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I 'm not afraid of hell ; I 've done nothing wrong .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: There is the dishonor that will fall on your children . You love your children , do you not ? Eh ? They will ask after you — they love you — because they do n't know — yet — ETCHEPAREsuddenly weepingMy poor little children ! My poor little children !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Come , then ! All good feeling is n't extinct in you . Believe me , Etchepare , the jury will be touched by your confession , by your repentance — you will escape the supreme penalty . You are still young — you have long years before you in which to expiate your crime . You may earn your pardon and perhaps you may once again see those children , who will have forgiven you . Believe me — believe me — in your own interests even , confess !Mouzon has approached Etchepare during the foregoing ; he places his hands on the latter 's shoulders ; he continues , with great gentlenessCome , is n't it true ? If you can n't speak , you 've only to nod your head . Eh ? It 's true ? Come , since I know it 's true . Eh ? I can n't hear what you say . It was you , was n't it ? It was you ! ETCHEPAREstill weepingIt was not me , sir ! I swear it was not me ! I swear it ! MOUZONin a hard voice , going back to his deskOh , you need n't swear . You have only to tell me the truth .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I am telling the truth — I am — I can n't say I did it when I did n't !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Come , come ! We shall get nothing out of you to-day .To the recorderRead him his interrogatory and let him be taken back to his cell . One minute — Etchepare !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Monsieur ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: There is one way to prove your innocence , since you profess to be innocent . Prove , in one way or another , that you were elsewhere than at Irissary on the night of the crime , and I will set you at liberty . Where were you ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Where was I ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I ask you where you were on the night of Ascension Day . Were you at home ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Is that really the truth ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Yes . MOUZONrising , rather theatrically , pointing at EtchepareNow , Etchepare , that condemns you . I know that you went out that night . When you were arrested you said to your wife , “ Do n't for the world admit that I went out last night . ” Come , I must tell you everything . Someone saw you — a servant . She told the gendarmes that as she was saying good-night to a young man from Iholdy , with whom she had been dancing , at ten o'clock at night , she saw you a few hundred yards from your house . What have you to say to that ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: It is true — I did go out . MOUZONtriumphantlyAh ! Now , my good man , we 've had some trouble in getting you to say something . But I can read it in your face when you are lying — I can read it in your face in letters as big as that . The proof is that there was no witness who saw you go out — neither your servant nor anyone else ; and yet I would have sworn to it with my head under the knife . Come , we have made a little progress now .To the recorderHave you put down carefully his first admission ? Good .To EtchepareNow think for a moment . We will continue our little conversation .He goes towards the fireplace , rubbing his hands , pours himself a glass of spirits , swallows it , gives a sigh of gratification , and returns to his chairFIRST GENDARMEto his comradeA cunning one , he is !

sp.speaker: SECOND GENDARME
sp.p: You 're right !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Let us continue . Come , now that you 've got so far , confess the whole thing ! Here are these good gendarmes who want to go to their grub .The gendarmes , the recorder , and Mouzon laughYou confess ? No ? Then tell me , why did you insist on saying that you remained at home that night ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Because I 'd told the gendarmes so and I did n't want to make myself out a liar .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: And why did you tell the gendarmes that ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Because I thought they 'd arrest me on account of the smuggling .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Good . Then you did n't go to Irissary that night ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Where did you go ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Up the mountain , to look for a horse that had got away the night before , one of a lot we were taking to Spain .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Good . Excellent . That is n't badly thought out — that can be maintained . You went to look for a horse lost on the mountain , a horse which escaped from a lot you were smuggling over the frontier on the previous night . Excellent . If that is true , there is nothing for it but to set you at liberty before we are much older . Now to prove that you 've simply to tell me to whom you sold the horse ; we shall send for the purchaser , and if he confirms your statement , I will sign your discharge . To whom did you sell the horse ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I did n't sell it .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You gave it away ? You did something with it !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No — I did n't find it again .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You did n't find it again ! The devil ! That 's not so good . Come ! Let 's think of something else . You did n't go up the mountain all alone ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Yes , all alone .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Bad luck ! Another time , you see , you ought to take a companion . Were you out long ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: All night . I got in at five in the morning .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: A long time .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: We are n't well off , and a horse is worth a lot of money .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Yes . But you did n't spend the whole night on the mountain without meeting someone — shepherds or customs officers ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: It was raining in torrents .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Then you met no one ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No one .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I thought as much .In a tone of disappointed reproach , with apparent pityTell me , Etchepare , do you take the jurymen for idiots ?SilenceSo that 's all you 've been able to think of ? I said you were intelligent just now . I take that back . But think what you 've told me — a rigmarole like that . Why , a child of eight would have done better . It 's ridiculous I tell you — ridiculous . The jurymen will simply shrug their shoulders when they hear it . A whole night out of doors , in the pouring rain , to look for a horse you do n't find — and without meeting a living soul — no shepherds , no customs officers — and you go home at five in the morning — although at this time of the year it 's daylight by then — yes , and before then — but no , no one saw you and you saw no one . So everybody was stricken with blindness , eh ? A miracle happened , and everyone was blind that night . You do n't ask me to believe that ? No ? Why not ? It 's quite as probable as what you do tell me . So everybody was n't blind ?The recorder bursts into a laugh ; the gendarmes imitate himYou see what it 's worth , your scheme of defence ! You make the gaolers and my recorder laugh . Do n't you agree with me that your new method of defence is ridiculous ? ETCHEPAREabashed , under his breathI do n't know .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , if you do n't know , we do ! Come now ! I have no advice to give you . You repeat that at the trial and see what effect you produce . But why not confess ? Why not confess ? I really do n't understand your obstinacy . I repeat , I really do not understand it .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Well , if I did n't do it , am I to say all the same that I did ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: So you persist in your story of the phantom horse ? You persist in it , do you ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: How do I know ? How should I know what I ought to say ? I should do better not to say anything at all — everything I say is turned against me !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Because the stories you invent are altogether too improbable — because you think me more of a fool than I am in thinking that I am going to credit such absurd inventions . I preferred your first method ; at least you had two witnesses to speak for you — two witnesses who were not worth very much , it 's true , but witnesses all the same . You 've made a change ; well , you are within your rights . Let us stick to the lost horse .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Well , then ?A long pause

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Come ! Out with it ! ETCHEPAREwithout emphasis , hesitation , gazing at the recorder as though to read in his eyes whether he was replying as he shouldWell , I 'm going to tell you , Monsieur . You are right — it is n't true — I did n't go up into the mountain . What I said first of all was the truth — I did n't go out at all . Just now I was all muddled . At first I denied everything , even what was true — I was so afraid of you . Then , when you told me — I do n't remember what it was — my head 's all going like — I do n't know — I do n't remember — but all the same I know I am innocent . Well , just now , I almost wished I could admit I was guilty if only you 'd leave me in peace . What was I saying ? I do n't remember . Ah , yes — when you told me — whatever it was , I 've forgotten — it seemed to me I 'd better say I 'd gone out — and I told a lie . Butsincerelywhat I swear to you is that I am not the guilty man . I swear it , I swear it !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I repeat , I ask nothing better than to be able to believe it . So now it 's understood , is it , that you were at home ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: We shall hear your wife directly . You have no other witnesses to call ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Good . Take the accused away — but remain in the Court . I shall probably need him directly for a confrontation . His interrogatory is n't finished . The gendarmes lead Etchepare away .

div.head: SCENE VIII :— Mouzon and the recorder .

stage.stage: MOUZON [ to the recorder ] What a rogue , eh ? One might have taken him in the act , knife in hand , and he 'd say it was n't true ! A crafty fellow too — he defends himself well .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: I really thought , at one time , that your worship had got him .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: When I was speaking of his children ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , that brought tears to one 's eyes . It made one feel one wanted to confess even though one had n't done anything !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Did n't it ? Ah , if I had n't got this headache !A pauseI did a stupid thing just now .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Oh , your worship !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I did . I was wrong to show him how improbable that new story of his was . It is so grotesque that it would have betrayed him — while , if he goes on asserting that he never left the house , if the servant insists he did n't , and if the wife says the same thing , that 's something that may create a doubt in the mind of the jury . He saw that perfectly , the rascal ! He felt that of the two methods the first was the better . That 's one against me , my good Benoît .To himselfThat must be set right . Let me think . Etchepare is the murderer , there 's no doubt about that . I am as certain of that as if I 'd been present . So he was n't at home on the night of the crime and his wife knows it . After the way he hesitated just now — if I can get the wife to confess that he was absent from home till the morning , we get back to the ridiculous story of the lost horse , and I catch him twice in a flagrant lie , and I 've got him . Come , we must give the good woman a bit of a roasting and get the truth out of her . It 'll be devilish queer if I do n't succeed .To the recorderWhat did I do with the police record of the woman Etchepare that was sent from Paris ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: It 's in the brief .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Yes — here it is — the extract from her judicial record . Report number two , a month of imprisonment , for receiving — could n't be better . Send her in . The recorder goes to the door and calls .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yanetta Etchepare !

div.stage: Enter Yanetta .
SCENE IX :— Mouzon , recorder , Yanetta .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Step forward . Now , Madame , I shall not administer the oath to you , since you are the wife of the accused . But none the less I beg you most urgently to tell the truth . I warn you that an untruth on your part might compel me to accuse you of complicity with your husband in the crime of which he is accused and force me to have you arrested at once .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I 'm not afraid . I can n't be my husband 's accomplice because my husband is n't guilty .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That is not my opinion . I will say further : you know a great deal more about this matter than you care to tell .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I ? That 's infamous .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Come , come , no shouting ! I do n't say you took a direct part in the murder , I say it is highly probable that you knew of the murder , perhaps advised it , and that you have profited by it . That would be enough to place you in the dock beside your husband at the assizes . My treatment of you will depend on the sincerity of your answers to my questions . As you do or do not tell me the truth I shall either set you at liberty or have you arrested . Now you can n't say that I have n't warned you ! And now , if you please , inform me whether you persist in your first statement , in which you affirm that Etchepare stopped at home on the night of Ascension Day .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I do .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , it is untrue . YANETTAexcitedThe night on which Daddy Goyetche was murdered my husband never left the house .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I tell you that is not the truth . YANETTAas beforeThe night Daddy Goyetche was murdered my husband never left the house .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You seem to have got stuck . You go on repeating the same thing .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , I go on repeating the same thing .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , now let us examine into the value of your evidence . Since your marriage — for the last ten years — your conduct has left nothing to be desired . You are thrifty , faithful , industrious , honest —

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Wait a moment . You have two children , whom you adore . You are an excellent mother . One hears of your almost heroic behavior at the time your eldest child was ill — Georges , I think .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , it was Georges . But what has that to do with the charge against my husband ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Have patience . You will see presently .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Very well .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It is all the more to your credit that you are what you are , for your husband does not give us an example of the same virtues . He occasionally gets drunk .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: No , he does n't .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Come — everyone knows that . He is violent .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: He 's not violent .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: So violent that he has been convicted four times for assault and battery .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: That 's possible ; at holiday times , in the evening , men get quarrelling . But that was a long time ago . Now he behaves better , and I 'm very happy with him .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That surprises me .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Anyhow , does that prove he murdered old Goyetche ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Your husband is very grasping .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Poor people are forced to be very grasping or else to die of starvation .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You defend him well .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Did you suppose I was going to accuse him ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Have you ever been convicted ? YANETTAanxiousMe ?

div.stage: Mouzon . Yes , you . YANETTA [ weakly ] No , I 've never been convicted .
Mouzon . That is curious because there was a girl of your name in Paris who was sentenced to a month 's imprisonment for receiving stolen property . YANETTA [ weakly ] For receiving stolen property —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You are not quite so bold now — you are disturbed . YANETTAas beforeNo —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You are pale — you are trembling — you are feeling faint . Give her a chair , Benoît .The recorder obeysPull yourself together !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: My God , you know that ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Here is the report which has been sent me . “ The woman Yanetta X — was brought to Paris at the age of sixteen as companion or lady 's maid by Monsieur and Madame So-and-so , having been employed by them in that capacity at Saint-Jean-de-Luz . ” Is that correct ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Here is some more . “ Illicit relations were before long formed between the girl Yanetta and the son of the family , who was twenty-three years of age . Two years later the lovers fled , taking with them eight thousand francs which the young man had stolen from his father . On the information of the latter the girl Yanetta was arrested and condemned to one month 's imprisonment for receiving stolen property . After serving her sentence she disappeared . It is believed that she returned to her own district . ” Are you the person mentioned here ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes . My God , I thought that was all so long ago — so completely forgotten . It is all true , Monsieur , but for ten years now I 've given every minute of my life to making up for it , trying to redeem myself . Just now I answered you insolently ; I beg your pardon . You have not only my life in your hands now , but my husband 's , and the honor of my children .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Does your husband know of this ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: No , Monsieur . Oh , you are n't going to tell him ! I beg you on my knees ! It would be wicked , I tell you , wicked ! Listen , Monsieur — listen . I came back to the country ; I hid myself ; I would rather have died ; I did n't want to stay in Paris — you understand why — and then in a little while I lost mother . Etchepare was in love with me , and he bothered me to marry him . I refused — I had the courage to go on refusing for three years . Then — I was so lonely , so miserable , and he was so unhappy , that in the end I gave way . I ought to have told him everything . I wanted to , but I could n't . It would have hurt him too much . For he 's a good man , Monsieur , I swear he is .Mouzon makes a gestureYes , I know , sometimes when he 's been drinking , he 's violent . I was going to tell you about that . I do n't want to tell you any more untruths . But it 's very seldom he 's violent now .WeepingOh , do n't let him know , Monsieur , do n't let him know . He 'd go away — he 'd leave me — he 'd take my children from me .She gives a despairing cryAh , he 'd take my children from me ! I do n't know what to say to you — but it is n't possible — you can n't tell him — now you know all the harm it would do . You wo n't ? Of course I was guilty — but I did n't understand — I did n't know . I was n't seventeen , sir , when I went to Paris . My master and mistress had a son ; he forced me almost — and I loved him — and then he wanted to take me away because his parents wanted to send him away by himself . I did what he asked me . That money — I did n't know he had stolen it — I swear I did n't know —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: That 's all right ; control yourself .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: We 'll put that on one side for the moment .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Now your husband —

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur . MOUZONwith great sincerityYou will have need of all your courage , my poor woman . Your husband is guilty .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: It 's impossible ! It 's impossible ! MOUZONwith great sincerityHe has not confessed it , but he is on the point of doing so . I myself know what happened that night after he left your house — witnesses have told me .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: No ! No ! My God , my God ! Witnesses ? What witnesses ? It is n't true !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well , then , do n't be so obstinate ! In your own interest , do n't be so stubborn ! Shall I tell you what will be the end of it ? You will ruin your husband ! If you insist on contradicting the evidence , that he passed the night away from the house , you 'll ruin him , I tell you . On the other hand , if you will only tell me the truth , then if he is not the murderer , he will tell us what he did do and who his companions were .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: He had n't any .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Then he went out alone ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: At ten o'clock ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: At ten .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: He returned alone at five in the morning ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , all alone .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: But perhaps you are thinking of some other night . It was really the night of Ascension Day when he went out alone ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Benoît , have you got that written down ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your worship .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Madame , I know how painful this must be to you , but I beg you to listen to me with the greatest attention . Your husband was pressed for money , was he not ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I tell you no .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Here is the proof . Three months ago he borrowed eight hundred francs from a cattle-dealer of Mauleon .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: He never told me about it .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Moreover , he owed a considerable sum to Goyetche .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I 've never heard of that either .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Here is an acknowledgment written by your husband . It is in his handwriting ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , but I did n't know —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You did n't know of the existence of this debt ? That tends to confirm what I know already — your husband went to Irissary .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: No , sir ; he tells me everything he does .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: But you see very well that he does n't , since you did n't know of the existence of this debt . He went to Irissary . Do n't you believe me ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur , but he did n't kill a man for money ; it 's a lie , a lie , a lie !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: It 's a lie ! Now how am I to know that ? Your husband begins by denying everything , blindly , and then he takes up two methods of defence in succession . You yourself begin by a piece of false evidence . All this , I tell you again , will do for the man .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I do n't know about that , but what I do tell you again is that he did n't kill a man for money .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Then what did he kill him for ? Perhaps after all he is n't as guilty as I supposed just now . Perhaps he acted without premeditation . This is what might have happened . Etchepare , a little the worse for drink , goes to Goyetche in order to ask him once more to wait for the payment of this debt . There is a dispute between the two men ; old Goyetche was still a strong man ; there may have been provocation on his part , and there may have been a struggle , with the tragic result you know of . In that case your husband 's position is entirely different — he is no longer a criminal premeditating a crime ; and the sentence pronounced against him may be quite a light one . So you see , my good woman , how greatly it is in your interest to obtain a complete confession from him . If he persists in his denials , I am afraid the jury will be extremely severe upon him . There is no doubt that he killed Goyetche ; but under what conditions did he kill him ? Everything depends on that . By persistently trying to pass for a totally innocent man he risks being thought more guilty than he is . Do you understand ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Will you speak to him as I suggest ? Shall I send for him ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: to the recorderBring in the accused . Tell the gendarmes I shall not need them . Etchepare enters .

div.stage: SCENE X :— The same , Etchepare .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Pierre ! To see you here — my Pierre — a prisoner — like a thief ! My poor husband — my poor husband ! Oh , prove you have n't done anything ! Tell his worship — tell him the truth . It 'll be best . I beg you tell him the truth .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: It 's all no good . I know , I can feel , I 'm done for . All that I can do or say would be no use . Every word I do say turns against me . The gentleman wants me to be guilty . I must be guilty , according to him . So you see ! What would you have me do , my poor darling ? I 've got no strength to go on struggling against him . Let them do what they like with me ; I sha n't say anything more .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , yes , you must speak . You must defend yourself . I beg of you , Pierre . I beg of you , defend yourself .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: What 's the use ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I beg you to in the name of your children . They do n't know anything yet — but they cry because they see me crying — because , you see , I can n't hide it , I can n't control myself always in front of them . I can n't be cheerful , can I ? And then they love me , so they notice it . And they ask me questions , questions . If you only knew ! They ask me about you . André was asking me again this morning , “ Where 's father ? Are you going to look for him ? Tell me , are you going to fetch him ? ” I told him “ yes ” and I ran away . You see you must defend yourself so as to get back to them as soon as possible . If you 've anything to reproach yourself with , even the least thing , tell it . You are rough sometimes — so — I do n't know . But if you went to Irissary , you must say so . Perhaps you had a quarrel with the poor old man . If that was it , say so , say so . Perhaps you got fighting together and you — I 'm saying perhaps you did — I do n't know — you understand — but his worship promised me just now that if it was like that they would n't punish you — or not very much . My God , what am I to say to you ? What 's to be done ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: So you believe I 'm guilty — you too ! Tell me now ! Do you believe me guilty too ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I do n't know ! I do n't know ! ETCHEPAREto MouzonAh , so you 've managed that too ; you 've thought of that too , to torture me through my wife — and it was you put it into her head to speak to me about my children . I do n't know what you can have told her , but you 've almost convinced her that I 'm a scoundrel , and you hoped she 'd succeed in sending me to the guillotine in the name of my children , because you know I worship them and they are everything to me . You are right ; I dare say there is n't another father living who loves his little ones more than I love mine .To YanettaYou know that , Yanetta ! You know that ! And you know too that with all my faults I 'm a true Christian , that I believe in God , in an almighty God . Well , then , listen ! My two boys — my little Georges , my little André — I pray God to kill them both if I 'm a criminal ! YANETTAwith the greatest exultationHe is innocent ! I tell you he 's innocent ! I tell you he 's innocent !A pauseAh , now you can bring your proofs , ten witnesses , a hundred if you like , and you might tell me you saw him do it — I should tell you : It 's not true ! It 's not true ! You might prove to me that he had confessed to it himself , and I would tell you it was n't true ! Oh , you must feel it , your worship . You have a heart — you know what it is when one loves one 's children — so you must be certain , you too , that he 's innocent . You are going to give him back to me , are n't you ? It 's settled now and you will give him back to me ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: If he is innocent , why did he lie just now ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: It was you who lied — you ! You told me you had witnesses who saw me leave my house that night — and you had n't anyone !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: If I had no one at that moment , I have someone now . Yes , there is a witness who has declared that you were not at home on the night of the crime , and that witness is your wife ! ETCHEPAREto YanettaYou ! MOUZONto the recorderGive me her interrogatory . While Mouzon looks through his papers Yanetta gazes for some time at her husband , then at Mouzon . She is reflecting deeply . Finally she seems to have made up her mind .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: There . Your wife has just told us that you left the house at ten o'clock and did not return until five in the morning . YANETTAvery plainlyI did not say that . It is not true .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You went on to say that he returned alone .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I did not say that .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I will read your declaration .He readsQuestion : Then he went out alone ? Reply : Yes . Question : At ten o'clock ? Reply : At ten o'clock .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I did not say that .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Come , come ! And I was careful to be precise . I said to you , “ But perhaps you are thinking of another night ? It was really on the night of Ascension Day that he went out alone ? ” And you replied , “ Yes . ”

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: It 's not so !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: But I have it written here !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: You can write whatever you like .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Then I 'm a liar . And the recorder too , he is a liar ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: The night old Goyetche was murdered my husband did not leave the house .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You will sign this paper , and at once . It is your interrogatory .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: All that is untrue ! I tell you it 's untrue !ShoutingThe night old Goyetche was murdered my husband never left the house — he never left the house . MOUZONpale with angerYou will pay for this !To the recorderMake out immediately an order for the detention of this woman and call the gendarmes .To YanettaWoman Etchepare , I place you under arrest on a charge of being accessory to murder .To the gendarmesTake the man to the cells and return for the woman . The gendarmes remove Etchepare .

div.stage: SCENE XI :— Mouzon , Yanetta , the recorder .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Ah , you are angry , are n't you — furious — because you have n't got your way ! Although you 've done everything , everything you possibly could , short of killing us by inches ! You pretend to be kind . You spoke kindly to us . You wanted to make me send my husband to the scaffold !Mouzon has taken up his brief and affects to be studying it with indifferenceIt 's your trade to supply heads to the guillotine . You must have criminals , guilty men , you must have them at any cost . When a man falls into your clutches he 's a dead man . They come in here innocent and they 've got to go out again guilty . It 's your trade ; it 's a matter of vanity with you to succeed ! You ask questions which do n't seem to mean anything in particular , and yet they may send a man to the next world ; and when you 've forced the poor wretch to condemn himself you 're delighted , like a savage would be ! MOUZONto the gendarmesTake her away — be quick !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , a savage ! You call that justice !To the gendarmesYou do n't take me like that , I tell you !She clings to the furnitureYou 're a butcher ! You are as cruel as the people in history who broke one 's bones to make one confess !The gendarmes have dragged her free ; she lets herself fall to the ground and shouts the rest of her speech while the men drag her to the door at the backBrute ! Savage brute ! No , you do n't think so — you think yourself a fine fellow , I have n't a doubt , and you 're a butcher —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Take her away , I tell you ! What , the two of you can n't rid me of that madwoman ? The gendarmes make a renewed effort .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Butcher ! Coward ! Judas ! Pitiless beast ! Yes , pitiless , and you are all the more dishonest and brutal when you 've got poor folk like us to do with .She is at the door , holding to the frameAh , the brutes , they are breaking my fingers ! Yes , the poorer one is the wickeder you are !They carry her away . Her cries are still heard as the curtain fallsThe poorer one is the more wicked you are — the poorer one is the more wicked you are —

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: The office of the District Attorney . A door to the left , set in a diagonal wall , gives on to a corridor . It opens inwardly , so that the lettering on the outside can be read : “ Parquet de Monsieur le Procureur de la République . ” A desk , chairs , and a chest of drawers .

div.head: SCENE I :— Benoît , La Bouzole . As the curtain rises the recorder is

stage.stage: removing various papers from the desk and placing them in a cardboard portfolio . Enter La Bouzole .

lg.stage: hesitating to take the hand which La Bouzole extends to him
lg.l: Your worship . It 's too great an honor —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Come , come , Monsieur Benoît , shake hands with me . From to-day I 'm no longer a magistrate ; my dignity no longer demands that I shall be impolite to my inferiors . How far have they got with the Etchepare trial ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: So far the hearing has been devoted entirely to the indictment and the counsel 's address .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: They will finish to-day ?

lg.l: Oh , surely . Even if Monsieur Vagret were to reply , because his
Honor the President of Assizes goes hunting to-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: You think it will be an acquittal , Monsieur Benoît ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: I do , your worship .He is about to go out

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Who is the old lady waiting in the corridor ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: That is Etchepare 's mother , your worship .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Poor woman ! She must be terribly anxious .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: No . She is certain of the verdict . She has n't the slightest anxiety . She was there all yesterday afternoon and she came back to-day , just as calm . Only to-day she wanted at any price to see the District Attorney or one of his assistants . Monsieur Ardeuil is away and Monsieur Vagret —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Is in Court .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: She seemed very much put out at finding no one .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Well , send her in here ; perhaps I can give her a little advice . Maître Plaçat will be some time yet , wo n't he ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: I believe so .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Well , tell her to come and speak to me , poor woman . That wo n't upset anybody and it may save her some trouble .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Very well , your worship .He goes to the door on the right , makes a sign to old Madame Etchepare , and goes out by the door at the backLA BOUZOLEaloneIt 's astonishing how benevolent I feel this morning ! Old Madame Etchepare enters , clad in the costume peculiar to old women of Basque race .

div.head: SCENE II :— La Bouzole , Old Madame Etchepare .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: They tell me , Madame , that you wished to see one of the gentlemen of the Bar .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: You wish to be present at the trial ?

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: No , sir . I know so well that they cannot condemn my son that what they say in there does n't interest me in the least . I am waiting for him . I have come because they have turned us out of our house .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: They have turned you out ?

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: The bailiffs came .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Then your son owed money ?

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Since they arrested him all our men have left us . We could n't get in the crops nor pay what was owing . But of course I know they 'll make all that good when my son is acquitted . LA BOUZOLEasidePoor woman !

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I 'm so thankful to see the end of all our troubles . He 'll come back and get our house and field again for us . He 'll make them give up our cattle . That 's why I wanted to see one of these gentlemen .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Will you explain ?

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: A fortnight after the gendarmes came to arrest my boy , Monsieur Claudet turned the waste water from his factory into the brook that passes our house where we water the beasts . That was one of the things that ruined us too . If Etchepare finds things like that when he gets back , God knows what he 'll do ! I want the law to stop them doing us all this harm .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: The law ! Ah , my good woman , it would be far better for you to have nothing to do with the law .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: But why ? There is justice , and it 's for everybody alike .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Has Monsieur Claudet the right —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Certainly not .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Then I want to ask the judge to stop him .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: It is not so simple as you suppose , Madame . First of all you must go to the bailiff .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Good .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: He will make a declaration .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: What about ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: He will declare that your water supply is contaminated .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: There is no need to trouble a bailiff , sir . A child could see that .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: It is the law .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Well , and then ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Then you must go to a lawyer and get a judgment .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Very well , if there ‘ s no other way of doing it —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: That is not all . If Monsieur Claudet contests the facts , the President will appoint an expert who will visit the site and make a report . You will have to put in a request that the President will grant a speedy hearing on grounds of urgency . Your case being finally put on the list of causes , it would be heard in its turn — after the vacations .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: After the vacations !

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: And that is not all . Monsieur Claudet 's lawyer might default , in which case judgment would be declared in your favor . But Monsieur Claudet might defend the case , or enter some kind of plea and obtain a judgment on that plea , or appeal against the judgment before the matter would be finally settled . All this would cost a great deal of money .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Who would pay it ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: You , naturally , and Monsieur Claudet .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: It 's all one to him ; he 's rich ; but for us , who have n't a penny left !

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Then you would have to apply for judicial assistance .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: That would take still more time ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: That would take much longer .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: But , sir , I 've always been told that justice was free in France .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Justice is gratuitous , but the means of obtaining access to justice are not . That is all .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: And all that would take — how long ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: If Monsieur Claudet were to appeal , it might last two years .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: It is n't possible ! Is n't the right on my side ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: My poor woman , it 's not enough to have the right on your side — you must have the law on your side too .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I understand . Justice is a thing we poor people can know only when it strikes us down . We can know it only by the harm it does us . Well — we must go away — it does n't matter where — and I sha n't regret it ; people insult us ; they call out to us as they pass . Etchepare would n't put up with that .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: In that respect the law protects you . Register a complaint and those who insult you will be prosecuted .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I do n't think so . I have already registered a complaint , as you say , but they 've done nothing to the man who injured us . So he goes on .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Is he an inhabitant of your commune ?

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Yes . A neighbor , a friend of Monsieur Mondoubleau , the deputy . Labastide .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Good . I will do what I can , I promise you .

sp.speaker: OLD MADAME ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Thank you , sir .A pauseThen I will go and wait till they give me back my boy .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: That 's right . She goes out slowly .

stage.stage: RECORDER [ entering by the door at the back ] The hearing is suspended , your worship .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Has Maître Plaçat concluded ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: With great applause . Two of the jurymen were seen wiping their eyes . No one doubts there will be an acquittal .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: So much the better .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Your worship knows the great news ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Which ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: That the Attorney-General has arrived .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: No — I know nothing of it .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , he has just arrived . It seems he brings the nomination of one of these gentlemen to the post of Councillor in the Court of Appeal .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Ah , ah ! And whose is the prize , in your opinion , Benoît ? Vagret 's ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: That was my opinion . I hesitated a long time between him and his Honor the President , and I decided it would be Monsieur Vagret . But now I think I am wrong .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Do you think Monsieur Bunerat is appointed ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: No , your worship . I feel very proud — I believe it is my employer who has the honor .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: Monsieur Mouzon !

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your worship .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: What makes you think that ?

lg.l: His Honor the Attorney-General requested me to beg Monsieur
Mouzon to come and speak to him before the rising of the Court .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: My congratulations , my dear Monsieur Benoît . Madame Bunerat enters .

div.head: SCENE IV :— The same and later Madame Vagret , Bunerat , the President of

stage.stage: Assizes , and Mouzon , then the Attorney-General .
MADAME BUNERAT [ in tears ] Oh , my dear Monsieur La Bouzole !

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: What has happened , Madame Bunerat ?

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: It 's that advocate ! What talent ! What a heart ! What feeling ! What genius ! I feel quite shaken — quite upset —

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: It 's an acquittal ?

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: They hope so — MADAME VAGRETenteringWell , my dear Monsieur La Bouzole , you have heard this famous advocate ! What a ranter !

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: It seems he has touched the jury . That means an acquittal .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: I 'm very much afraid it does .

div.stage: Enter Bunerat in a black gown .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Do you know what they tell me ? The Attorney-General is here !

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: Really !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Are you certain ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: It is true enough . He brings Monsieur Mouzon his appointment to the Court of Appeal at Pau .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Mouzon !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET AND MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: And my husband ! We had a definite promise ! The President of Assizes enters , wearing a red gown .

lg.l: Good-day , gentlemen . You have not seen the

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: No , your honor — but if you will wait —

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: No . Tell me , La Bouzole — you are an old stager — were you in Court ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: From the balloting for the jurymen to the plea for the defence .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Did you notice if I let anything pass that would make an appeal to the Court of Cassation possible ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: I am sure you did n't .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: It 's my constant fear — I am thinking of nothing else all the time counsel are speaking . I always have the Manual of the President of Assizes wide open in front of me ; I 'm always afraid , nevertheless , of forgetting some formality . You see the effect of being in the Chancellery — I never have a quiet conscience until the time-limit has expired .A pauseThey tell me there were journalists here from Toulouse and Bordeaux .

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: And one from Paris .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: One from Paris ! Are you sure ?

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: He was standing near the prisoner 's bench .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: He was left to stand ! A journalist from Paris and he was left to stand !Catching sight of the recorderYou knew that , Monsieur the recorder , and you did n't warn me ? Is that how you perform your duties ? Go at once and express my regret and find him a good seat ; do you hear ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your honor .He turns to goTHE PRESIDENTrunning after himHere !Aside to the recorderFind out if he 's annoyed .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , your honor .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: And then —He encounters Madame Bunerat at the door . Pardon , Madame . He goes out , running , lifting up his gown

sp.speaker: LA BOUZOLE
sp.p: When I was at Montpellier I knew an old tenor who was as anxious as that at his third début — Enter Mouzon . Frigid salutations . MADAME BUNERATafter a pauseIs it true , Monsieur Mouzon —

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: That the Attorney-General —

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Has arrived ? MOUZONhaughtilyQuite true .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: They say he brings a councillor 's appointment .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: They say so .

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: And you do n't know ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: You do n't know ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
