sp.p: Nothing at all .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Does nothing lead you to suppose —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Nothing . RECORDERenteringHere is his Honor the Attorney-General .

sp.speaker: MADAME BUNERAT
sp.p: Oh , Lord ! She arranges her hair . Enter the Attorney-General , a man with handsome , grave , austere features . ALLbowing and cringing , in a murmurHis Honor the Attorney-General —

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: I think you can resume the hearing , gentlemen — I am only passing through Mauleon . I hope to return before long and make your better acquaintance .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Your honor —They make ready to leave

lg.stage: to the recorder , who is about to leave
lg.l: I believe my appointment is settled .

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: I am delighted , Monsieur the Councillor !Exit

div.head: SCENE V :— Mouzon , Attorney-General . Mouzon rubs his hands together ,

stage.stage: bubbling with joy .
MOUZON [ obsequiously ] Your honor —

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Sit down .Mouzon does soA report has come to my office from Bordeaux — which concerns you , Monsieur !Feeling in his portfolioHere it is .ReadingMouzon and the woman Pecquet . You know what it is ? MOUZONnot taking the matter seriously , forces a smile . After a long silenceYes , your honor —

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: I am waiting for your explanation . MOUZONas beforeYou have been young , your honor —

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Not to that extent , Monsieur !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I admit I overstepped the mark a trifle . ATTORNEY-GENERALreading“ Being in a state of intoxication , together with the woman Pecquet and two other women of bad character who accompanied him , the aforesaid Mouzon used insulting and outrageous language to the police , whom he threatened with dismissal . ” Is that what you call overstepping the mark a trifle ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Perhaps the expression is a little weak .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: And you allow the name of a magistrate to be coupled in a police report with that of the woman Pecquet ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: She told me her name was Diane de Montmorency .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: continuing“ Questioned by us , the commissary of police , on the following morning , as to the rank of officer in the navy which he had assumed ” —The Attorney-General gazes at Mouzon . Another pauseMOUZONstill smilingYes , it 's on account of my whiskers , you know .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: When I — oh , well — when I go to Bordeaux I always assume the rank of naval officer , in order to safeguard the dignity of the law .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: You seem to have been a little tardy in considering it .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I beg you to note , your honor , that I endeavored to safeguard it from the very first , since I took care to go out of the arrondissement and even the judicial division — in order to —

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: I will continue . “ Monsieur Mouzon then informed us of his actual position as examining magistrate , and invoked that quality in requesting that we would stop proceedings . ”

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: The ass . He has put that in his report ? Oh , really — that 's due to his lack of education . No , it 's a political affair — the commissary is one of our opponents — I asked him — After all — I wanted to avoid scandal . Anyone would have done the same in my place .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Is that the only explanation you have to give me ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Explanation ? The truth is , Monsieur , that if you insist on maintaining , in this conversation , the relations between a superior and a subordinate , I can give you no further explanation . But if you would be so good as to allow me for a moment to forget your position , if you would agree to talk to me as man to man , I should tell you that this was a fault of youth , regrettable , no doubt , but explained by the profound boredom which exudes from the very paving-stones of Mauleon . Come , come ! I had dined too well . Every night of the year a host of decent fellows find themselves in the same case . It 's a pecadillo which does n't affect one 's personal honor .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Monsieur , when one has the honor to be a magistrate — when one has accepted the mission of judging one 's fellows , one is bound more than all others to observe temperance and to consider one 's dignity in all things . What may not affect the honor of the private citizen does affect the honor of the judge . You may take that for granted .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: As you refuse to discuss the matter otherwise than in an official manner , nothing remains for me but to beg you to inform me what you have decided to do .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Cannot you guess ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I am an examining magistrate . You will make me an ordinary magistrate . It means my income will be diminished by five hundred francs a year . I accept .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: It is unfortunately impossible for me to content myself with such a simple measure . To speak plainly , I must inform you that Monsieur Coire , the director of the newspaper which attacks us so persistently , is acquainted with the whole of the facts of the accusation brought against you and will not give his word not to publish them unless by the end of the month you have left the Mauleon Court . I therefore find myself in the unhappy necessity of demanding your resignation .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I shall not resign .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: You will not resign ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I am distressed to oppose any desire of yours , but I am quite decided . I shall not resign .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: But really — you cannot know —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I know everything . ATTORNEY-GENERAL . Very well , sir , we shall proceed against you .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Proceed .He rises

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Are you not alarmed at the scandal which would result from your appearance in court and your probable conviction ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Conviction is less probable than you think . I shall be able to defend myself and to select my advocate . As for the scandal , it would n't fall on me . I am a bachelor , with no family ; I know no one or next to no one in Mauleon , where I am really in exile . My friends are all in Bordeaux ; they belong to the monde ou l'on s'amuse , and I should not in the least lose caste in their eyes on account of such a prosecution . You think I ought to leave the magistracy ? Fortunately I have sufficient to live on without the thirty-five hundred francs the Government of the Republic allows me annually .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: That is enough , Monsieur . Good-day .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: My respects .He goes out

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: Monsieur the deputy is here , your honor . Monsieur the deputy says that your honor is waiting for him .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: That is so . Ask him to come in .

div.stage: Enter Mondoubleau . The Attorney-General advances towards him and shakes hands with him .

div.head: SCENE VI :— Mondoubleau , Attorney-General .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Good-day , my dear Attorney-General .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Good-day , my dear deputy .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I 'm delighted to see you . I 've come from Paris . I had lunch yesterday with my friend the Keeper of the Seals . The Government is badly worried just at the moment .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: About what ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: They 're afraid of an interpellation . Just a chance — I 'll tell you about it . Tell me — it seems you have a young assistant here who has been playing pranks .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Monsieur Ardeuil ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Ardeuil , yes , that 's the man . Eugène follows matters very closely .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Eugène ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Eugène — my friend Eugène — the Keeper of the Seals . He said to me , “ I expect your Attorney-General to understand how to do his duty . ”

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: I ask nothing better , but let me know what my duty is .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: That 's just what one wants to avoid . But look here , my friend , you are a very mysterious person ! ATTORNEY-GENERAL . I ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: You are asking for a change of appointment .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Who told you that ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Who do you suppose ? He is the only one who knows .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Eug —QuicklyThe Keeper of the Seals ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: You want to be appointed to Orléans ? Am I correctly informed ?

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Quite true . We have relations there .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I fancy you are concerned in the movement now in preparation .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Is there a movement in preparation ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: There is . As for Monsieur Ardeuil , the Minister confined himself to saying that he had confidence in your firmness and zeal .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: The Keeper of the Seals may rely on me . I shall have to show considerable severity in several directions here , and I shall lack neither determination nor zeal , I can assure you .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Yes , but above all , tact ! Eugène repeated a dozen times , “ Above all , no prosecutions , no scandals . At the present moment less than ever . We are being watched . So everything must be done quietly . ”

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: You need n't be alarmed . There 's the matter of Mouzon .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Mouzon ! Mouzon the examining magistrate !

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Of Mauleon ?

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Precisely .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: You are n't thinking of — One of my best friends — very well disposed — a capital fellow — an excellent magistrate , full of energy and discernment . I mentioned his name to Eugène in connection with the vacant post of Councillor .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: offering him the reportYou 've picked the wrong man . I am going to show you a document about him . Besides , the post is promised to Monsieur Vagret .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: What is wrong ?

lg.l: Here . I shall have to report him to the Superior
Council of the Magistracy or proceed against him in the Court of Appeal .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: What has he done ?

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Read it . MONDOUBLEAUafter casting a glance over the document which the other has handed to himOf course . But really — there 's nothing in that . If you keep quiet about it , no one will know anything . No scandal . The magistracy is suffering from too many attacks already just now , without our providing our enemies with weapons .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Unfortunately Coire knows of it , and he threatens to tell the whole story in his paper unless Monsieur Mouzon is sent away from Mauleon .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: The devil !He begins to laugh

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: What are you laughing at ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Nothing — an extravagant idea , a jest .He laughsTell me — but you wo n't be annoyed ?— it 's only a joke —

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I was thinking — I tell you , it 's a grotesque idea . But after all — after all , if you propose Mouzon for the Councillor 's chair at Pau , you will be pleasing everyone !

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: My dear deputy —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: A joke — of course , merely a joke — but what 's so amusing about it is that if you did so it would please Coire , it would please me , it would please Mouzon , and it would please Eugène , who does n't want any scandal .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: But it would be a —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: No , no . In politics there can be no scandal except where there is publicity .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: But really —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: I agree with you — I know all that could be said — I repeat , I am only chaffing . And do you realize — it 's very curious — when one reflects — this fantastic solution is the only one that does not offer serious disadvantages — obvious disadvantages . That is so . If you leave Mouzon here , Coire tells everything . If you proceed against him , you give a certain section of the press an opportunity it wo n't lose — an opportunity of sapping one of the pillars of society . Those gentry are not particular as to the means they employ . They will confound the whole magistracy with Mouzon . It wo n't be Mouzon who will be the rake , but the Court , the Court of Appeal . There will be mud on all — on every robe .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: But you can n't seriously ask me —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Do you know what we ought to do ? Let us go and talk it over with Rollet the senator — he is only a step from here .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: I assure you —

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: Come — come . You will put in a word as to your going to Orléans at the same time . What have you to risk ? I tell you my solution is the best . You will come to it , I assure you ! I 'll take you along .He takes his arm

lg.l: Well , well , I had certainly something to say to

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: Your honor —

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Where are they ? The verdict —?

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: Not yet . Monsieur Vagret has been making a reply .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Is the jury in the withdrawing room ?

sp.speaker: DOORKEEPER
sp.p: No , your honor . They were going out when Monsieur Vagret asked for an adjournment .

sp.speaker: MONDOUBLEAU
sp.p: What an idea ! Really ! Well , my friend , let us go . I tell you , you 'll come round ! ATTORNEY-GENERALweaklyNever ! Never !

div.stage: SCENE VII :— Recorder , then the doorkeeper , then Madame Vagret , the President of Assizes , Bunerat , Madame Bunerat , and Vagret . RECORDER [ much moved ] Admirable ! DOORKEEPER [ half opening the door at the back ] Monsieur Benoît ! What 's the news ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Splendid ! Our Prosecutor was admirable — and that Etchepare is the lowest swine .

div.stage: Enter Madame Vagret , greatly moved . The recorder goes up to her . The doorkeeper disappears .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Ah ! My God !

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Madame Vagret , I am only a simple clerk , but allow me to say it was admirable ! Wonderful !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Wonderful !

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: As for the counsel from Bordeaux , Monsieur Vagret had him absolutely at his mercy !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Had n't he ?

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: He 's certain enough , now , to be condemned to death !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Certain !

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: Madame , the jurymen were looking at that fellow Etchepare , that thug , in a way that made my blood run cold . As Monsieur Vagret went on with his speech you felt they would have liked to settle his hash themselves — the wretch !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: I saw that —

sp.speaker: RECORDER
sp.p: I beg your pardon , Madame — I am forgetting myself — but there are moments when one is thankful , yes , so gratified , that social differences do n't count .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: You are right , my dear man .

div.stage: Enter the President of Assizes and Bunerat .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Madame , I congratulate you ! We 've got it , the capital sentence !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: We have it safely this time , have n't we , Monsieur ?

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: That is certain . But where is our hero ? Magnificent — he was magnificent — was n't he , Bunerat ?

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Oh , sir , but the manner in which you presided prepared the way so well —

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Well , well , I do n't say I count for nothing in the result , but we must do justice to Vagret .To Madame VagretYou ought to be greatly gratified — very proud and happy , my dear Madame —

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Oh , I am , your honor —

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: But what a strange idea to demand an adjournment ! Is he unwell ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Oh , dear !

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: No . Here he is .

div.stage: Enter Vagret . He is anxious .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Ah , my dear !She takes his hand in hers . She can say no more , being choked by tears of joy

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: It was wonderful !

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: I can n't restrain myself from congratulating you too .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Really , you confuse me . The whole merit is yours , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Not at all . Do you know what carried them all away ?He lights a cigarette

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: It was when you exclaimed , “ Gentlemen of the jury , you own houses , farms , and property ; you have beloved wives , and daughters whom you tenderly cherish . Beware — ” You were splendid there !Resuming“ Beware , if you leave such crimes unpunished ; beware , if you allow yourselves to be led astray by the eloquent sentimentality of the defence ; beware , I tell you , if you fail in your duty as the instrument of justice ; beware , lest those above you snatch up the sword which has fallen from your feeble hands , when the blood that you have not avenged will be spilt upon you and yours ! ” That was fine ! Very fine ! And it produced a great effect .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: But you , my dear President , you moved them even more noticeably when you recalled the fact , very appropriately , that the accused loved the sight of blood .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Ah , yes , that told a little !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: What ? What was that ?

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: The President put this question : “ On the morning of the crime did you not slaughter two sheep ? ” “ Yes , ” replied the accused . And then , looking him straight in the eyes —

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Yes , I asked him : “ You were getting into practice , were n't you ? ”To VagretBut after all , if I have to a certain extent affected the result , the greater part of the honor of the day is yours .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: You are too kind .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Not at all ! And your peroration !With an artist 's curiosityYou were really , were you not , under the stress of a great emotion , a really great emotion ? VAGRETgravelyYes , I was under the stress of a great emotion , a really great emotion .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: You turned quite pale when you faced the jury — when you added , in a clear voice , “ Gentlemen , I demand the head of this man ! ” VAGREThis eyes fixedYes .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Then you made a sign to the advocate .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes . I thought he would have something else to say .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: But why delay the verdict ? You had won the victory .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Precisely .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: During my indictment a fact came to light that worried me .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: A fact ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Not a fact — but — in short —A pauseI beg your pardon — I am very tired —

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: I can very well understand your emotion , my dear Vagret . One always feels — on the occasion of one 's first death sentence — but — you will see one gets used to it .Going out , to BuneratIndeed , he does look very tired .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: I fancy he is feeling his position too keenly .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: As I was leaving the Court I met the Attorney-General . I begged him urgently to give me a moment 's conversation . I wanted to speak with him alone — and with you , Monsieur le Président .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: As you wish .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: I am afraid you are unwell , my dear . I shall wait there . I will come back directly these gentlemen have gone .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Very well . MADAME BUNERATgoing out , to her husbandThere 's a man ready to do something stupid .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: That does n't concern us . They go out .

div.head: SCENE VIII :— Vagret , the President of Assizes , then the

stage.stage: Attorney-General .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Did you notice any mistake on my part in the direction of the case ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: No , if any mistake was made , it was I who made it . The Attorney-General enters .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: What is this that is so serious , my dear sir ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: It 's this — I am more worried than I can say . I want to appeal to the conscience of you two gentlemen — to reassure myself —

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Tell us .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: A whole series of facts — the attitude of the accused — certain details which had escaped me — have given rise , in my mind , to a doubt as to the guilt of this man .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Was there any mention of these facts , these details , in the brief ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Had the advocate studied this brief ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Naturally .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Well , then ? What are you worrying yourself about ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: But — suppose the man is not guilty ?

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: The jury will decide . We can do no more , all of us , than bow to its verdict .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Let me tell you , sir , how my convictions have been shaken .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: I do not wish to know . All that is a matter between yourself and your conscience . You have the right to explain your scruples to the jury . You know the proverb : “ The pen is a slave , but speech is free . ”

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I shall follow your advice .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: I do not give you any advice .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I shall explain my doubts to the jury .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: It will mean acquittal .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: What would you have ?

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Do as you wish ; but I should like to tell you one thing . When a man plans a startling trick of this kind and has the courage to accomplish it entirely of his own accord , he must have the courage to accept the sole responsibility of the blunders he may commit . You are too clever ; you want to discover some means by which you need not be the only one to suffer from the consequences of your vacillations .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Clever ? I ? How ?

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Come , come ! We are not children , and I can perfectly well see the trap into which you have lured me . You are sheltering yourself behind me . If the Chancellery should complain of your attitude , you will say that you consulted your superior , and I shall be the victim . And then I shall have a quarrel with the Chancellery on my hands . You do n't care , you do n't think of my position or my interests , of which you know nothing . Some silly idea gets into your head , and against my will you want to make me responsible for it . I say again , it is extremely clever , and I congratulate you , but I do n't thank you .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: You have misunderstood me , sir . I have no wish to burden you with the responsibilities I am about to assume . I should hardly choose the moment when I am on the point of being appointed Councillor to perpetrate such a blunder . I told you of my perplexity , and I asked your advice . That was all .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Are you certain one way or the other ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: If I were certain , should I ask advice ?A pauseIf we only had a cause for cassation , a good — THE PRESIDENTenragedWhat 's that you say ? Cause for cassation ? Based on an error or on an oversight on my part , no doubt ! Really , you have plenty of imagination ! You are attacked by certain doubts , certain scruples — I do n't know what — and in order to quiet your morbidly distracted conscience you ask me kindly to make myself the culprit ! Convenient , in truth , to foist on others who have done their duty the blunders one may have committed oneself ! ATTORNEY-GENERALquietlyIt is indeed .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: And at the Chancellery , when they mention me , they 'll say , “ Whatever sort of a councillor is this , who has n't even the capacity to preside over an Assize Court at Mauleon ! ” A man whom we 've taken such trouble to get condemned ! And to make me , me , the victim of such trickery ! No , no ! Think of another way , my dear Monsieur ; you wo n't employ that , I can assure you .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Then I shall seek other means ; but I shall not leave matters in their present state .

sp.speaker: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
sp.p: Do what you like , but realize that I have given you no advice in one direction or another .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I realize that .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: When you have decided to resume the hearing you will notify us .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I will notify you . ATTORNEY-GENERALto the PresidentLet us go . They leave the office .

div.stage: SCENE IX :— Vagret , Madame Vagret .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Nothing ? You are so depressed — and yet you 've just had such a success as will tell on your career .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: It is that success which alarms me .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Alarms you ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes , I 'm afraid —

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Afraid of what ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Of having gone too far .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Too far ! Does n't the murderer deserve death ten times over ? VAGRETafter a pauseAre you quite certain , yourself , that he is a murderer ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Yes . VAGRETin a low voiceWell — for myself —

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: You ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I — I do n't know . I know nothing .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: My God !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: A dreadful thing happened to me in the course of my indictment . While I , the State Attorney , the official prosecutor , was exercising my function , another self was examining the case calmly , in cold blood ; an inner voice kept reproaching me for my violence and insinuating into my mind a doubt , which has gone on increasing . A painful struggle has been going on in my mind , a cruel struggle — and if , as I was finishing , I labored under that emotion of which the President was speaking , if when I demanded the death penalty my voice was scarcely audible , it was because I was at the end of my struggle ; because my conscience was on the point of winning the battle , and I made haste to finish , because I was afraid it would speak out against my will . When I saw the advocate remain seated and that he was not going to resume his speech in order to tell the jury the things I would have had him tell them — then I was really afraid of myself , afraid of my actions , of my words , of their terrible consequences , and I wanted to gain time .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: But , my dear , you have done your duty ; if the advocate has not done his , that does not concern you .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Always the same reply . If I were an honest man I should tell the jury , when the hearing is resumed , of the doubts that have seized me . I should explain how those doubts arose in me ; I should call their attention to a point which I deliberately concealed from them , because I believed the counsel for the defence would point it out to him .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: You know , my dear , how thoroughly I respect your scruples , but allow me to tell you all the same that it wo n't be you who will declare Etchepare guilty or not guilty ; it will be the jury . If anyone ought to feel disturbed , it is Maître Plaçat , not you —

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: But I ought to represent justice !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Here is a prisoner who comes before you with previous convictions , with a whole crushing series of circumstances establishing his guilt . He is defended by whom ? By one of the ornaments of the Bar , a man famed for his conscience as much as for his ability and his oratorical skill . You expound the facts to the jury . If the jury agrees with you , I cannot see that your responsibility as a magistrate is involved .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I do n't think about my responsibility as a magistrate — but my responsibility as a man is certainly involved ! No ! No ! I have not the right . I tell you there is a series of circumstances in this case of which no one has spoken and the nature of which makes me believe in the innocence of the accused .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: But — these circumstances — how was it you knew nothing of them until now ? VAGREThis head droopingDo you think I did know nothing of them ? My God ! Shall I have the courage to tell you everything ? I am not a bad man , am I ? I would n't wish anyone to suffer for a fault of mine — but — oh , I am ashamed to admit it , to say it aloud , even , when I have admitted it to myself ! Well , when I was studying the brief , I had got it so firmly fixed in my mind , to begin with , that Etchepare was a criminal , that when an argument in his favor presented itself to my mind , I rejected it utterly , shrugging my shoulders . As for the facts of which I am speaking , and which gave rise to my doubts — at first I simply tried to prove that those facts were false , taking , from the depositions of the witnesses , only that which would militate against their truth and rejecting all the rest , with a terrible simplicity of bad faith . And in the end , in order to dissipate my last scruples , I told myself , just as you told me , “ That is the business of the defence ; it is n't mine ! ” Listen , and you 'll see to what point the exercise of the magistrate 's office distorts our natures , makes us unjust and cruel . At first I had a feeling of delight when I saw that the President , in his cross-examination , was throwing no light whatever on this series of little facts . It was my profession speaking in me , my profession , do you see ? Oh , what poor creatures we are , what poor creatures !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Perhaps the jury wo n't find him guilty ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: It will find him guilty .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Or it may find there are extenuating circumstances .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: No . I adjured them too earnestly to refuse to do so . I was zealous enough , was n't I ? Violent enough ?

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: That 's true . Why did you make your indictment so passionately ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Ah , why , why ? Long before the hearing of the case it was so clearly understood by everybody that the prisoner was the criminal ! And then it all went to my head , it intoxicated me — the way they talked . I was the spokesman of humanity , I was to reassure the countryside , I was to restore tranquillity to the family , and I do n't know what else ! So then — I felt I must show myself equal to the part intrusted to me . My first indictment was relatively moderate — but when I saw the celebrated counsel making the jurymen weep , I thought I was lost ; I felt the verdict would escape me . Contrary to my habit , I replied . When I rose to my feet for the second time I was like a man fighting , who has just had a vision of defeat , and who therefore fights with the strength of despair . From that moment Etchepare , so to speak , no longer existed . I was no longer concerned to defend society or sustain my accusation ; I was contending against the advocate ; it was a trial of orators , a competition of actors ; I had to be the victor at all costs . I had to convince the jury , resume my hold on it , wring from it the double “ yes ” of the verdict . I tell you , Etchepare no longer counted ; it was I who counted , my vanity , my reputation , my honor , my future . It 's shameful , I tell you , shameful . At any cost I wanted to prevent the acquittal which I felt was certain . And I was so afraid of not succeeding that I employed every argument , good and bad , even that of representing to the terrified jurymen their own houses in flames , their own flesh and blood murdered . I spoke of the vengeance of God falling on judges without severity . And all this in good faith — or rather unconsciously , in a burst of passion , in an access of anger against the advocate , whom I hated at that moment with all my might . My success was greater than I hoped ; the jury is ready to obey me ; and I , my dear , I have allowed myself to be congratulated , I have grasped the hands held out to me . That is what it is to be a magistrate !

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: Never mind . Perhaps there are n't ten in all France who would have acted otherwise .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: You are right . Only — if one reflects — it 's precisely that that 's so dreadful . RECORDERenteringMonsieur le Procureur , the President is asking when the sitting can be resumed .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: At once .

sp.speaker: MADAME VAGRET
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: My duty as an honest man .He makes ready to go

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: ACT IV
div.stage: SCENES — Same as the Second Act .

div.head: SCENE I : - Bunerat , the President of Assizes , and Vagret .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Well , your honor , there 's another session finished . THE PRESIDENTin red robeI 've been in a blue funk lest these brutes would make me lose my train . I 'm going shooting to-morrow on the Cambo Ponds , you see , my dear fellow , and after to-night 's train it 's no go .Looks at his watchOh , I 've an hour and a half yet .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: And what do you think of it , your honor ?

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Of what ? Of the acquittal ? What does it matter to me ? I do n't care — on the contrary , I prefer it . I am certain the advocate wo n't ferret out some unintentional defect — some formality gone wrong . Where 's my hat-box ? He is about to stand on a chair to reach the hat-box , which is on the top of a cupboard . Bunerat precedes him .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Permit me , Monsieur . You are at home here .From the chairI believe I shall have the pleasure of seeing you here again next session .He sighs , holding out the hat-box

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: A pleasure I shall share , my dear fellow .He takes out a small felt hat from the box

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Would you like a brush ? There 's Mouzon 's brush .A sighAh , good God , when shall I leave Mauleon ? I should so like to live at Pau !

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Pooh ! A much overrated city ! Come , come !

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: I suppose my new duties wo n't take me there yet ?

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Do n't you worry yourself . In the winter , yes , it 's very well — but the summer — ah , the summer .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: I am not the one appointed ?

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Ah ! You know already ?

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Yes — I — yes — that is to say , I did n't know it was official . THE PRESIDENTbrushing his hat and catching sight of a dentDented already . In these days the hats they sell you for felt , my dear chap , they 're paste-board , simply —

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: True . Yes , I did n't know it was official . Monsieur Mouzon is very lucky .

div.stage: Enter Vagret in mufti .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: There , there is our dear Monsieur Vagret . Changed your dress already . Yes , you 're at home , you . For my part I must pack up all this . Where the devil is the box I put my gown in ?Bunerat makes a step to fetch it and then remains motionlessIt 's curious — that — what have they done with it ? In that cupboard — you have n't seen it , my dear Monsieur Bunerat ?

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Ah , here it is — and my jacket in it .He opens the box and takes out his jacket , which he lays aside on the tableWell , well , you 've got them acquitted , my dear sir ! Are you satisfied ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I am very glad .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: And if they are the murderers ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I must console myself with Berryer 's remark : “ It is better to leave ten guilty men at liberty than to punish one innocent man . ”

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: You have a sensitive nature .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Ought one to have a heart of stone , then , to be a magistrate ? THE PRESIDENTtying up the box in which he has put his judge 's bonnetOne must keep oneself above the little miseries of humanity .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Above the miseries of others .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Hang it all —

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: That is what we call egoism .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Do you say that for my benefit ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: For all three of us .

sp.speaker: BUNERAT
sp.p: Au revoir , gentlemen . Au revoir .He shakes hands with each and goes outTHE PRESIDENTtaking off his gownMy dear Monsieur , I beg you to be more moderate in your remarks .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Ah , I assure you that I am moderate ! If I were to speak what is in my mind , you would hear very unpleasant things . THE PRESIDENTin shirt sleevesAre you forgetting to whom you are speaking ? I am a Councillor of the Court , Monsieur le Procureur .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Once again , I am not speaking to you merely ; the disagreeable things I might say would condemn me equally . I am thinking of those poor people . THE PRESIDENTbrushing his gownWhat poor people ? The late prisoners ? But after all , they are acquitted . What more do you want ? To provide them with an income ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: They are acquitted , true ; but they are condemned , all the same . They are sentenced to misery for life .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: What are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: And through your fault , Monsieur . THE PRESIDENTstopping in his task of folding his gownMy fault !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: And what is so particularly serious is that you did n't know it , you did n't see , you have n't seen the harm you did .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: What harm ? I have done no harm ! I ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: When you informed Etchepare that his wife had long ago been condemned for receiving stolen goods , and that she had been seduced before his marriage with her . When you did that you did a wicked thing .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: You are a Don Quixote . Do you suppose Etchepare did n't know all that ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: If you had noticed his emotion when his wife , on your asking her if the facts were correct , replied that they were , you would be certain , as I am , that he knew nothing . THE PRESIDENTpacking his gown in its boxWell , even so ! You attribute to people of that sort susceptibilities which they do n't possess .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Your honor , “ people of that sort ” have hearts , just as you and I have .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Admitted . Did n't my duty force me to do as I did ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I know nothing about that . THE PRESIDENTstill in shirt sleevesIt 's the law that is guilty , then , eh ? Yes ? Well , Monsieur , if I did my duty — and I did — you are lacking in your duty in attacking the law , whose faithful servant you should be , the law which I , for one , am proud to represent .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: There 's no reason for your pride .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Monsieur !

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: It 's a monstrous thing , I tell you , that one can reproach an accused person , whether innocent or guilty , with a fault committed ten years ago , and which has been expiated . Yes , Monsieur , it is a horrible thing that , after punishing , the law does not pardon . THE PRESIDENTwho has put on his jacket and hatIf you think the law is bad , get it altered . Enter Parliament .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Alas , if I were a deputy , it is probable that I should be like the rest ; instead of thinking of such matters I should think of nothing but calculating the probable duration of the Government . THE PRESIDENThis box under his armIn that case — is the doorkeeper — VAGRETtouching a bellHe will come . Then it 's Monsieur Mouzon who is appointed in my place ?

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: It is Monsieur Mouzon .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Because he 's the creature of a deputy , a Mondoubleau —

lg.l: I cannot allow you to speak ill of Monsieur

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: You think you may perhaps have need of him .

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
sp.p: Precisely .The doorkeeper appearsWill you carry that to my hotel for me ? The hotel by the station . You will easily recognize it ; my sentry is at the door .He hands the doorkeeper his boxesAu revoir , my dear Vagret — no offence taken .

div.stage: He goes . Vagret puts on his hat and also makes ready to go . Enter recorder and Etchepare .

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: You are going , your honor ?

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: You wo n't have any objection , then , if I bring Etchepare in here ? He 's in the corridor , waiting for the formalities of his release — and he complains he 's an object of curiosity to everyone .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Of course !

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: I 'll tell them to bring his wife here too when she leaves the record office .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Very well .

lg.l: I am just going to warn the warders — but the woman
Etchepare can n't be released immediately .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: She 's detained in connection with another case . She 's charged with abusing a magistrate in the exercise of his duty .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Is that magistrate Monsieur Mouzon ?

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: Yes , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: I will try to arrange that .

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: Good-day , your honor .

sp.speaker: VAGRET
sp.p: Good-day .

stage.stage: THE RECORDER [ at the door ] Etchepare — come in . You had better wait here for your final discharge . It wo n't take much longer .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Thank you , Monsieur .

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: Well , there you are , then , acquitted , my poor fellow ! There 's one matter done with .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: It 's finished as far as justice is concerned , Monsieur ; it is n't finished for me . I 'm acquitted , it 's true , but my life is made miserable .

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: You did n't know —

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: That 's it .

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: It 's a long time ago — you 'll forgive her .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Things like that , Monsieur — a Basque never forgives them . It 's as though a thunderbolt had struck me to the heart . And all the misfortune that 's befallen us — it 's she who is the cause — God has avenged himself . Everything 's over . THE RECORDERafter a pauseI am sorry for you with all my heart .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Thank you , Monsieur .A pauseSince you are so kind , Monsieur , will you allow my mother , who 's there in the corridor , waiting for me , to come and speak to me ?

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: I 'll send her in to you . Good-bye .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.head: SCENE III :— The recorder goes out . Enter Etchepare 's mother .

stage.stage: ETCHEPARE [ pressing his mother 's head against his breast ] Poor old mother — how the misery of these three months has changed you !

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: My poor boy , how you must have suffered !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: That woman !

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: Yes , they 've just been telling me .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: For ten years I 've lived with that thief — that wretched woman ! How she lied ! Ah ! When I heard that judge say to her , “ You were convicted of theft and complicity with your lover , ” and when , before all those people , she owned to it — I tell you , mummy , I thought the skies were falling on my head — and when she admitted she 'd been that man 's mistress — I do n't know just what happened — nor which I would have killed soonest — the judge who said such things so calmly or her who admitted them with her back turned to me . And then I was on the point of confessing myself guilty — I , an innocent man — in order not to learn any more — to get away — but I thought of you and the children !A long pauseCome ! We 've got to make up our minds what we 're going to do . You left them at home ?

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: No . I had to send them to our cousin at Bayonne . We 've no longer got a home — we 've nothing — we are ruined . Besides , I 've got a horror of this place now . The women edge away and make signs to one another when I meet them , and in the church they leave me all alone in the middle of an empty space . Already — I had to take the children away from school .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: My God !

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: No one would speak to them . One day Georges picked a quarrel with the biggest , and they fought , and as Georges got the better of it , the other , to revenge himself , called him the son of a gallows-bird .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: And Georges ?

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: He came home crying and would n't go out of doors . It was then that I sent them away to Bayonne .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: That 's what we 'll do . Go away . We 'll go and fetch them . To-morrow or to-night I shall be with you again . There are emigration companies there — boats to America — they 'll send all four of us — they 'll give us credit for the voyage on account of the children .

lg.l: And when they ask for their mother —

div.head: SCENE IV :— Yanetta is shown in .

stage.stage: YANETTA [ to someone outside ] Very good , Monsieur . [ The door is closed ]
THE MOTHER [ without looking at Yanetta ] Then I 'll go .
ETCHEPARE [ the same ] Yes . I shall see you again to-night or down there to-morrow .

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: Very well .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Directly you get there you 'll go and find out about the day and hour .

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: Very well .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Till to-morrow then .

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: To-morrow .She goes out without glancing at YanettaYANETTAtakes a few steps towards her husband , falls on her knees , and clasps her hands . In a low voiceForgive me !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Never !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Do n't say never !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Was the judge lying ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: No — he was n't lying .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: You wretched thing !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , I am a wretched thing ! Forgive me !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Kill you rather ! I could kill you !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes , yes ! But forgive me !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: You 're just a loose woman — a loose woman from Paris , with no honor , no shame , no honesty even !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Yes ! Insult me — strike me !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: For ten years you have been lying to me !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Oh , how I wished I could have told you everything ! Oh , how many times I began that dreadful confession ! I never had courage enough . I was always afraid of your anger , Pierre , and of the pain I should cause you — I saw you were so happy !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: You came from up there , fresh from your vice , fresh from prison , and you chose me to be your gull .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: My God , to think he believes that !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: You brought me the leavings of a swindler — the leavings of a swindler — and you stole , in my house , the place of an honest woman ! Your lies have brought the curse of God on my family and it 's you who are the cause of everything . The misfortune that 's just befallen us , it 's you who are the cause of it , I tell you ! You 're a pest , accursed , damned ! Do n't say another word to me ! Do n't speak to me !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Have you no pity , Pierre ? Do you suppose I 'm not suffering ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: If you are suffering you 've deserved it ! You have n't suffered enough yet . But what had I ever done to you that you should choose me for your victim ? What did I ever do that I should have to bear what I 'm suffering ? You 've made me a coward — you 've lowered me almost to your own level — I ought to have been able to put you out of my mind and my heart already ! And I can n't ! And I 'm suffering torture , terrible torture — for I 'm suffering through the love I once had for you . You — you were everything to me for ten years — my whole life . You 've been everything , everything ! And now the one hope left me is that I may forget you !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Oh , forgive me !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Never ! Never !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Do n't say that word — only God has the right to say — never ! I will come back to you . I 'll be only like the head servant — no , the lowest if you like ! I wo n't take my place in the home again until you tell me to .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: We have no house ; we have no home . Nothing is left now ! And I tell you again it 's your fault — and it 's because you used to be there , in the mother 's place , my mother 's place , you , a lie and a sacrilege — it 's because of that that misfortune has overtaken us !

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I swear to you I 'd make you forget it all in time — I 'd be so humble , so devoted , so repentant . And wherever you go I shall follow you . Pierre — think , your children still need me .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: My children ! You shall never see them again ! You shall never speak to them . I wo n't have you kiss them . I wo n't have you even touch them ! YANETTAchanging her toneAh , no , not that , not that ! The children ! No , you are wrong there ! You can deprive me of everything — you can put every imaginable shame upon me — you can force me to beg my bread — I 'll do it willingly . You need n't look at me — you need n't speak to me except to abuse me — you can do anything , anything you like . But my children , my children — they are mine , the fruit of my body — they are still part of me — they are blood of my blood and bone of my bone forever . You might cut off one of my arms , and my arm would be a dead thing , and no part of myself any more , but you can n't stop my children being my children .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: You have made yourself unworthy to keep them .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Unworthy ! What has unworthiness to do with it ? Have I ever failed in my duty to them ? Have I been a bad mother ? Answer me ! I have n't , have I ? Well then , if I have n't been a bad mother , my rights over them are as great as ever they were ! Unworthy ! I might be a thousand times more guilty — more unworthy , as you call it — but neither you , nor the law , nor the priests , nor God himself would have the right to take them from me . I have been to blame as a wife , it 's possible , but as a mother I 've nothing to reproach myself with . Well then — well then — no one can steal them from me ! And you , who could think of such a thing , you 're a wretch ! Yes , it 's to avenge yourself that you want to part me from them ! You 're just a coward ! Just a man ! There 's no fatherhood left in your heart — you do n't think of them . Yes — you are lying — I tell you , you are lying ! When you say I 'm not worthy to bring them up you 're lying ! It 's only a saying — only words . You know it is n't true — you know I 've nourished them , cared for them , loved them , consoled them , and I have taught them to say their prayers every night , and I would go on doing so . You know that no other woman will ever fill my place — but that makes no difference to you . You forget them — you want to punish me , so you want to take them from me . I 'm justified in saying to you that it 's an act of cowardly wickedness and a vile piece of vengeance ! Ah ! The children ! You want to gamble with them now . No — to take them away from me — think , Pierre , think ; it is n't possible , what you are saying !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: You are right ; I am revenging myself ! What you think an impossibility is done already . My mother has taken the children and gone away with them .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I shall find them again .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: America is a big country .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I shall find them again !

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: Then I shall tell them why I have taken them away from you !

lg.l: Never ! Never that ! I 'll obey you , but swear —

sp.speaker: THE RECORDER
sp.p: Etchepare , come and sign your discharge . You will be released at once .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Wait a moment , Monsieur , wait a moment .To EtchepareI agree to separation if I must . I will disappear — you will never hear of me again . But in return for this wicked sacrifice swear solemnly that you will never tell them .

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I swear .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: You swear never to tell them anything that may lessen their affection for me ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I swear .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Promise me too — I beg you , Pierre — in the name of our happiness and my misery — promise to keep me fresh in their memory — let them pray for me , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: ETCHEPARE
sp.p: I swear it .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Then go — my life is done with .

lg.l: He goes out with the recorder . At the door the latter meets
They are coming to show you the way out .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Ah , she 's there . Monsieur Vagret has been speaking of her . Well , I withdraw my complaint ; I ask nothing better than that she shall be set at liberty . Now that I am a Councillor I do n't want to be coming back from Pau every week for the examination . Proceed with the necessary formalities .

div.head: SCENE V :— Mouzon , Yanetta , the recorder .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Well — in consideration of the time you have been in custody , I am willing that you should be set at liberty — provisional liberty . I may , perhaps , even withdraw my complaint if you express regret for having insulted me . YANETTAcalmlyI do not regret having insulted you .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Do you want to go back to prison ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: My poor man , if you only knew how little it matters to me whether I go to prison or not !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Because I have nothing left , neither house , nor home , nor husband , nor children .She looks at himAnd — I think — I think —

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You think ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I think it is you who are the cause of all the trouble .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: You are both acquitted , are n't you ? What more do you ask ?

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: We have been acquitted , it is true . But all the same , I am no longer an honest woman — neither to my husband , nor to my children , nor to the world .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: If anyone reproaches you with the penalty inflicted upon you formerly , if anyone makes any illusion to the time you have spent in custody under remand , you have the right to prosecute the offender in the courts . He will be punished .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Well ! It is because someone reproached me with that old conviction that my husband has taken my children from me . That someone is a magistrate . Can I have him punished ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Why not ? Because he is a magistrate ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: No . Because he is the law .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: The law !ViolentlyThen the law is wicked , wicked !

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: Come , no shouting , no insults , please .To the recorderHave you finished ? Then go to the office and have an order made out for her discharge .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: I 'm no scholar ; I 've not studied the law in books , like you , and perhaps for that very reason I know better than you what is just and what is not . And I want to ask you a plain question : How is the law going to give me back my children and make up to me for the harm it 's done me ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: The law owes you nothing .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: The law owes me nothing ! Then what are you going to do — you , the judge ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: A magistrate is not responsible .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Ah , you are not responsible ! So you can arrest people just as you like , just when you fancy , on a suspicion or even without a suspicion ; you can bring shame and dishonor on their families ; you can torture the unhappy , ferret into their past lives , expose their misfortunes , dig up forgotten offences , offences which have been atoned for and which go back to ten years ago ; you can make use of your skill , your tricks and lies , and your cruelty to send a man to the foot of the scaffold , and worse still , you can drive people into taking a mother 's children away from her — and after that you say , like Pontius Pilate , that you are n't responsible ! Not responsible ! Perhaps you are n't responsible in the eyes of this law of yours , since you tell me you are n't , but in the eyes of pure and simple justice , the justice of decent people , the justice of God , before that I swear you are responsible , and that is why I am going to call you to account ! She sees on Mouzon 's desk the dagger which he uses as a paper-knife . He turns his back on her . She seizes the knife and puts it down again .

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I order you to get out of here .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: Listen to me . For the last time I ask you — what do you think you can do to make up to me — to give me back all I 've lost through your fault ; what are you going to do to lessen my misery , and how do you propose to give me back my children ?

sp.speaker: MOUZON
sp.p: I have nothing to say to you . I owe you nothing .

sp.speaker: YANETTA
sp.p: You owe me nothing ! You owe me more than life — more than everything . My children I shall never see again . What you 've taken from me is the happiness of every moment of the day — their kisses at night — the pride I felt in watching them grow up . Never , never again shall I hear them call me “ mother . ” It 's as though they were dead — it 's as though you had killed them .She seizes the knifeYes ! That 's your work ; it 's you bad judges have done it ; you have nearly made a criminal of an innocent man , and you force an honest woman , a mother — to become a criminal ! She stabs him . He falls .

div.stage: CURTAIN .
